They do not work in Canvas mode games.Note 2: You must use a build of Phaser that includes the CreatureMeshBone.js runtime and gl-matrix.js, or have themloaded before your Phaser game boots.See the Phaser custom build process for more details.By default the Creature runtimes are NOT included in any pre-configured version of Phaser.So you'll need to do `grunt custom` to create a build that includes them.

constructor.name: Creature
constructor.description: Creature is a custom Game Object used in conjunction with the Creature Runtime libraries by Kestrel Moon Studios.It allows you to display animated Game Objects that were created with the [Creature Automated Animation Tool](http://www.kestrelmoon.com/creature/).Note 1: You can only use Phaser.Creature objects in WebGL enabled games. They do not work in Canvas mode games.Note 2: You must use a build of Phaser that includes the CreatureMeshBone.js runtime and gl-matrix.js, or have themloaded before your Phaser game boots.See the Phaser custom build process for more details.By default the Creature runtimes are NOT included in any pre-configured version of Phaser.So you'll need to do `grunt custom` to create a build that includes them.

parameters.name: game

Destroy this DisplayObject.
Removes all references to transformCallbacks, its parent, the stage, filters, bounds, mask and cached Sprites.

Useful function that returns a texture of the displayObject object that can then be used to create sprites

functions.description: Internal method.

parameters.description: The render session

functions.name: update
functions.description: Override this method in your own custom objects to handle any update requirements.It is called immediately after `preUpdate` and before `postUpdate`.Remember if this Game Object has any children you should call update on those too.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method called by the World postUpdate cycle.

functions.name: bringToTop
functions.description: Brings this Game Object to the top of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render over the top of any old child in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will bring it to the top of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: sendToBack
functions.description: Sends this Game Object to the bottom of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render below all other children in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will send it to the bottom of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: Moves this Game Object up one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the top of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object up within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: Moves this Game Object down one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the bottom of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object down within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: revive
functions.description: Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: kill
functions.description: Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool, it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

members.name: pivot
members.description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

members.name: rotation
members.description: The rotation of the object in radians.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The opacity of the object.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility of the object.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description: Can this object be rendered

members.name: parent
members.description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

members.name: stage
members.description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

members.name: worldTransform
members.description: [read-only] Current transform of the object based on world (parent) factors

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: _sr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: _cr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: filterArea
members.description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

members.name: _bounds
members.description: The original, cached bounds of the object

members.name: _currentBounds
members.description: The most up-to-date bounds of the object

members.name: _mask
members.description: The original, cached mask of the object

members.name: _cacheAsBitmap
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: _cacheIsDirty
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.
In PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.
To remove a mask, set this property to null.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for the displayObject.
IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the Canvas renderer.

To remove filters simply set this property to 'null'.

You cannot have a filter and a multiply blend mode active at the same time. Setting a filter will reset
this objects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.
This basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.
To remove simply set this property to 'null'

members.name: x
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: y
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A user defined name given to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, it is meant as a game level property.

members.name: components
members.description: The components this Game Object has installed.

members.name: z
members.description: The z depth of this Game Object within its parent Group.No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.This value is adjusted automatically whenever the Group hierarchy changes.

members.name: events
members.description: All Phaser Game Objects have an Events class which contains all of the events that are dispatched when certain things happen to thisGame Object, or any of its components.

members.name: animations
members.description: If the Game Object is enabled for animation (such as a Phaser.Sprite) this is a reference to its AnimationManager instance.Through it you can create, play, pause and stop animations.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the image or texture used by this Game Object during rendering.If it is a string it's the string used to retrieve the texture from the Phaser Image Cache.It can also be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.If a Game Object is created without a key it is automatically assigned the key `__default` which is a 32x32 transparent PNG stored within the Cache.If a Game Object is given a key which doesn't exist in the Image Cache it is re-assigned the key `__missing` which is a 32x32 PNG of a green box with a line through it.

members.name: world
members.description: The world coordinates of this Game Object in pixels.Depending on where in the display list this Game Object is placed this value can differ from `position`, which contains the x/y coordinates relative to the Game Objects parent.

members.name: debug
members.description: A debug flag designed for use with `Game.enableStep`.

members.name: previousPosition
members.description: The position the Game Object was located in the previous frame.

members.name: previousRotation
members.description: The rotation the Game Object was in set to in the previous frame. Value is in radians.

members.name: renderOrderID
members.description: The render order ID is used internally by the renderer and Input Manager and should not be modified.This property is mostly used internally by the renderers, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: fresh
members.description: A Game Object is considered `fresh` if it has just been created or reset and is yet to receive a renderer transform update.This property is mostly used internally by the physics systems, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Game Object is that is pendingDestroy is flagged to have its destroy method called on the next logic update.You can set it directly to allow you to flag an object to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy an object from within one of its own callbacks such as with Buttons or other Input events.

members.name: _exists
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if this Game Object is processed by the core game loop.If this Game Object has a physics body it also controls if its physics body is updated or not.When `exists` is set to `false` it will remove its physics body from the physics world if it has one.It also toggles the `visible` property to false as well.Setting `exists` to true will add its physics body back in to the physics world, if it has one.It will also set the `visible` property to `true`.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle property is the rotation of the Game Object in *degrees* from its original orientation.Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees you can use the property `rotation` instead. Working in radians is slightly faster as it doesn't have to perform any calculations.

members.name: autoCull
members.description: A Game Object with `autoCull` set to true will check its bounds against the World Camera every frame.If it is not intersecting the Camera bounds at any point then it has its `renderable` property set to `false`.This keeps the Game Object alive and still processing updates, but forces it to skip the render step entirely.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: inCamera
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds intersect with the Game Camera bounds.Returns `true` if they do, otherwise `false` if fully outside of the Cameras bounds.

members.name: destroyPhase
members.description: As a Game Object runs through its destroy method this flag is set to true, and can be checked in any sub-systems or plugins it is being destroyed from.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Game Object that is "fixed" to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera during rendering.The values are adjusted at the rendering stage, overriding the Game Objects actual world position.The end result is that the Game Object will appear to be 'fixed' to the camera, regardless of where in the game worldthe camera is viewing. This is useful if for example this Game Object is a UI item that you wish to be visible at all times regardless where in the world the camera is.The offsets are stored in the `cameraOffset` property.Note that the `cameraOffset` values are in addition to any parent of this Game Object on the display list.Be careful not to set `fixedToCamera` on Game Objects which are in Groups that already have `fixedToCamera` enabled on them.

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: The x/y coordinate offset applied to the top-left of the camera that this Game Object will be drawn at if `fixedToCamera` is true.The values are relative to the top-left of the camera view and in addition to any parent of the Game Object on the display list.

members.name: alive
members.description: A useful flag to control if the Game Object is alive or dead.This is set automatically by the Health components `damage` method should the object run out of health.Or you can toggle it via your game code.This property is mostly just provided to be used by your game - it doesn't effect rendering or logic updates.However you can use `Group.getFirstAlive` in conjunction with this property for fast object pooling and recycling.

members.name: lifespan
members.description: The lifespan allows you to give a Game Object a lifespan in milliseconds.Once the Game Object is 'born' you can set this to a positive value.It is automatically decremented by the millisecond equivalent of `game.time.physicsElapsed` each frame.When it reaches zero it will call the `kill` method.Very handy for particles, bullets, collectibles, or any other short-lived entity.

classes.name: Phaser.GameObjectCreator
classes.description: The GameObjectCreator is a quick way to create common game objects _without_ adding them to the game world.The object creator can be accessed with {@linkcode Phaser.Game#make `game.make`}.

constructor.name: GameObjectCreator
constructor.description: The GameObjectCreator is a quick way to create common game objects _without_ adding them to the game world.The object creator can be accessed with {@linkcode Phaser.Game#make `game.make`}.

parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

functions.name: image
functions.description: Create a new Image object.An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events. This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the image.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the image.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If the sprite uses an image from a texture atlas or sprite sheet you can pass the frame here. Either a number for a frame ID or a string for a frame name.

returns.description: the newly created sprite object.

parameters.name: outFrame

functions.name: emitter
functions.description: Creat a new Emitter.An Emitter is a lightweight particle emitter. It can be used for one-time explosions or forcontinuous effects like rain and fire. All it really does is launch Particle objects outat set intervals, and fixes their positions and velocities accorindgly.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate within the Emitter that the particles are emitted from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate within the Emitter that the particles are emitted from.

parameters.name: maxParticles
parameters.description: The total number of particles in this emitter.

returns.description: The newly created emitter object.

functions.name: retroFont
functions.description: Create a new RetroFont object.A RetroFont can be used as a texture for an Image or Sprite and optionally add it to the Cache.A RetroFont uses a bitmap which contains fixed with characters for the font set. You use character spacing to define the set.If you need variable width character support then use a BitmapText object instead. The main difference between a RetroFont and a BitmapTextis that a RetroFont creates a single texture that you can apply to a game object, where-as a BitmapText creates one Sprite object per letter of text.The texture can be asssigned or one or multiple images/sprites, but note that the text the RetroFont uses will be shared across them all,i.e. if you need each Image to have different text in it, then you need to create multiple RetroFont objects.

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The key of the image in the Game.Cache that the RetroFont will use.

parameters.name: characterWidth
parameters.description: The width of each character in the font set.

parameters.name: characterHeight
parameters.description: The height of each character in the font set.

parameters.name: chars
parameters.description: The characters used in the font set, in display order. You can use the TEXT_SET consts for common font set arrangements.

parameters.name: charsPerRow
parameters.description: The number of characters per row in the font set.

parameters.name: xSpacing
parameters.description: If the characters in the font set have horizontal spacing between them set the required amount here.

parameters.name: ySpacing
parameters.description: If the characters in the font set have vertical spacing between them set the required amount here.

parameters.name: xOffset
parameters.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the X coordinate offset here.

parameters.name: yOffset
parameters.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the Y coordinate offset here.

returns.description: The newly created RetroFont texture which can be applied to an Image or Sprite.

functions.name: bitmapText
functions.description: Create a new BitmapText object.BitmapText objects work by taking a texture file and an XML file that describes the font structure.It then generates a new Sprite object for each letter of the text, proportionally spaced out and aligned to match the font structure.BitmapText objects are less flexible than Text objects, in that they have less features such as shadows, fills and the ability to use Web Fonts. However you trade this flexibility for pure rendering speed. You can also create visually compelling BitmapTexts by processing the font texture in an image editor first, applying fills and any other effects required.To create multi-line text insert \r, \n or \r\n escape codes into the text string.To create a BitmapText data files you can use:BMFont (Windows, free): http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/Glyph Designer (OS X, commercial): http://www.71squared.com/en/glyphdesignerLittera (Web-based, free): http://kvazars.com/littera/

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The key of the BitmapText as stored in Phaser.Cache.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text that will be rendered. This can also be set later via BitmapText.text.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size the font will be rendered at in pixels.

parameters.name: align
parameters.description: The alignment of multi-line text. Has no effect if there is only one line of text.

returns.description: The newly created bitmapText object.

functions.name: tilemap
functions.description: Creates a new Phaser.Tilemap object.The map can either be populated with data from a Tiled JSON file or from a CSV file.To do this pass the Cache key as the first parameter. When using Tiled data you need only provide the key.When using CSV data you must provide the key and the tileWidth and tileHeight parameters.If creating a blank tilemap to be populated later, you can either specify no parameters at all and then use `Tilemap.create` or pass the map and tile dimensions here.Note that all Tilemaps use a base tile size to calculate dimensions from, but that a TilemapLayer may have its own unique tile size that overrides it.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the tilemap data as stored in the Cache. If you're creating a blank map either leave this parameter out or pass `null`.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The pixel width of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The pixel height of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

functions.name: renderTexture
functions.description: A dynamic initially blank canvas to which images can be drawn.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: the width of the RenderTexture.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: the height of the RenderTexture.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Asset key for the RenderTexture when stored in the Cache (see addToCache parameter).

parameters.name: addToCache
parameters.description: Should this RenderTexture be added to the Game.Cache? If so you can retrieve it with Cache.getTexture(key)

returns.description: The newly created RenderTexture object.

functions.name: bitmapData
functions.description: Create a BitmpaData object.A BitmapData object can be manipulated and drawn to like a traditional Canvas object and used to texture Sprites.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the BitmapData in pixels.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the BitmapData in pixels.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Asset key for the BitmapData when stored in the Cache (see addToCache parameter).

parameters.name: addToCache
parameters.description: Should this BitmapData be added to the Game.Cache? If so you can retrieve it with Cache.getBitmapData(key)

returns.description: The newly created BitmapData object.

functions.name: filter
functions.description: A WebGL shader/filter that can be applied to Sprites.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The name of the filter you wish to create, for example HueRotate or SineWave.
Whatever parameters are needed to be passed to the filter init function.

returns.description: The newly created Phaser.Filter object.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: world
members.description: A reference to the game world.

classes.name: Phaser.GameObjectFactory
classes.description: The GameObjectFactory is a quick way to create many common game objectsusing {@linkcode Phaser.Game#add `game.add`}.Created objects are _automatically added_ to the appropriate Manager, World, or manually specified parent Group.

constructor.name: GameObjectFactory
constructor.description: The GameObjectFactory is a quick way to create many common game objectsusing {@linkcode Phaser.Game#add `game.add`}.Created objects are _automatically added_ to the appropriate Manager, World, or manually specified parent Group.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

functions.name: existing
functions.description: Adds an existing display object to the game world.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: An instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Button or any other display object.

returns.description: The child that was added to the World.

functions.name: image
functions.description: Create a new `Image` object.An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events. This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The newly created Image object.

functions.name: sprite
functions.description: Create a new Sprite with specific position and sprite sheet key.At its most basic a Sprite consists of a set of coordinates and a texture that is used when rendered.They also contain additional properties allowing for physics motion (via Sprite.body), input handling (via Sprite.input),events (via Sprite.events), animation (via Sprite.animations), camera culling and more. Please see the Examples for use cases.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the sprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this sprite may be in.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the sprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this sprite may be in.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The newly created Sprite object.

functions.name: creature
functions.description: Create a new Creature Animation object.Creature is a custom Game Object used in conjunction with the Creature Runtime libraries by Kestrel Moon Studios.It allows you to display animated Game Objects that were created with the [Creature Automated Animation Tool](http://www.kestrelmoon.com/creature/).Note 1: You can only use Phaser.Creature objects in WebGL enabled games. They do not work in Canvas mode games.Note 2: You must use a build of Phaser that includes the CreatureMeshBone.js runtime and gl-matrix.js, or have themloaded before your Phaser game boots.See the Phaser custom build process for more details.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the creature. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this creature may be in.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the creature. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this creature may be in.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The image used as a texture by this creature object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The newly created Sprite object.

functions.name: tween
functions.description: Create a tween on a specific object.The object can be any JavaScript object or Phaser object such as Sprite.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: Object the tween will be run on.

returns.description: The newly created Phaser.Tween object.

functions.name: group
functions.description: A Group is a container for display objects that allows for fast pooling, recycling and collision checks.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent Group or DisplayObjectContainer that will hold this group, if any. If set to null the Group won't be added to the display list. If undefined it will be added to World by default.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

parameters.name: addToStage
parameters.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.

parameters.name: enableBody
parameters.description: If true all Sprites created with `Group.create` or `Group.createMulitple` will have a physics body created on them. Change the body type with physicsBodyType.

parameters.name: physicsBodyType
parameters.description: If enableBody is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites. Phaser.Physics.ARCADE, Phaser.Physics.P2, Phaser.Physics.NINJA, etc.

returns.description: The newly created Group.

functions.name: physicsGroup
functions.description: A Group is a container for display objects that allows for fast pooling, recycling and collision checks.A Physics Group is the same as an ordinary Group except that is has enableBody turned on by default, so any Sprites it createsare automatically given a physics body.

parameters.name: physicsBodyType
parameters.description: If enableBody is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites. Phaser.Physics.ARCADE, Phaser.Physics.P2, Phaser.Physics.NINJA, etc.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent Group or DisplayObjectContainer that will hold this group, if any. If set to null the Group won't be added to the display list. If undefined it will be added to World by default.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

parameters.name: addToStage
parameters.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.

returns.description: The newly created Group.

functions.name: spriteBatch
functions.description: A SpriteBatch is a really fast version of a Phaser Group built solely for speed.Use when you need a lot of sprites or particles all sharing the same texture.The speed gains are specifically for WebGL. In Canvas mode you won't see any real difference.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent Group that will hold this Sprite Batch. Set to `undefined` or `null` to add directly to game.world.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A name for this Sprite Batch. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

parameters.name: addToStage
parameters.description: If set to true this Sprite Batch will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of the parent.

returns.description: The newly created Sprite Batch.

functions.name: audio
functions.description: Creates a new Sound object.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The Game.cache key of the sound that this object will use.

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: The volume at which the sound will be played.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Whether or not the sound will loop.

parameters.name: connect
parameters.description: Controls if the created Sound object will connect to the master gainNode of the SoundManager when running under WebAudio.

returns.description: The newly created sound object.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Override this method in your own custom objects to handle any update requirements.It is called immediately after `preUpdate` and before `postUpdate`.Remember if this Game Object has any children you should call update on those too.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method called by the World postUpdate cycle.

functions.name: revive
functions.description: Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: kill
functions.description: Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool, it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: fillAlpha
members.description: The alpha value used when filling the Graphics object.

members.name: lineWidth
members.description: The width (thickness) of any lines drawn.

members.name: lineColor
members.description: The color of any lines drawn.

members.name: graphicsData
members.description: Graphics data

members.name: tint
members.description: The tint applied to the graphic shape. This is a hex value. Apply a value of 0xFFFFFF to reset the tint.

members.name: blendMode
members.description: The blend mode to be applied to the graphic shape. Apply a value of PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to reset the blend mode.

members.name: currentPath
members.description: Current path

members.name: _webGL
members.description: Array containing some WebGL-related properties used by the WebGL renderer.

members.name: isMask
members.description: Whether this shape is being used as a mask.

members.name: boundsPadding
members.description: The bounds' padding used for bounds calculation.

members.name: dirty
members.description: Used to detect if the graphics object has changed. If this is set to true then the graphics object will be recalculated.

members.name: webGLDirty
members.description: Used to detect if the webgl graphics object has changed. If this is set to true then the graphics object will be recalculated.

members.name: cachedSpriteDirty
members.description: Used to detect if the cached sprite object needs to be updated.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
When cacheAsBitmap is set to true the graphics object will be rendered as if it was a sprite.
This is useful if your graphics element does not change often, as it will speed up the rendering of the object in exchange for taking up texture memory.
It is also useful if you need the graphics object to be anti-aliased, because it will be rendered using canvas.
This is not recommended if you are constantly redrawing the graphics element.

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: position
members.description: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: scale
members.description: The scale factor of the object.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

members.name: pivot
members.description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

members.name: rotation
members.description: The rotation of the object in radians.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The opacity of the object.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility of the object.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description: Can this object be rendered

members.name: parent
members.description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

members.name: stage
members.description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

members.name: worldTransform
members.description: [read-only] Current transform of the object based on world (parent) factors

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: _sr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: _cr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: filterArea
members.description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

members.name: _bounds
members.description: The original, cached bounds of the object

members.name: _currentBounds
members.description: The most up-to-date bounds of the object

members.name: _mask
members.description: The original, cached mask of the object

members.name: _cacheAsBitmap
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: _cacheIsDirty
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.
In PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.
To remove a mask, set this property to null.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for the displayObject.
IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the Canvas renderer.

To remove filters simply set this property to 'null'.

You cannot have a filter and a multiply blend mode active at the same time. Setting a filter will reset
this objects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: x
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: y
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A user defined name given to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, it is meant as a game level property.

members.name: components
members.description: The components this Game Object has installed.

members.name: z
members.description: The z depth of this Game Object within its parent Group.No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.This value is adjusted automatically whenever the Group hierarchy changes.

members.name: events
members.description: All Phaser Game Objects have an Events class which contains all of the events that are dispatched when certain things happen to thisGame Object, or any of its components.

members.name: animations
members.description: If the Game Object is enabled for animation (such as a Phaser.Sprite) this is a reference to its AnimationManager instance.Through it you can create, play, pause and stop animations.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the image or texture used by this Game Object during rendering.If it is a string it's the string used to retrieve the texture from the Phaser Image Cache.It can also be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.If a Game Object is created without a key it is automatically assigned the key `__default` which is a 32x32 transparent PNG stored within the Cache.If a Game Object is given a key which doesn't exist in the Image Cache it is re-assigned the key `__missing` which is a 32x32 PNG of a green box with a line through it.

members.name: world
members.description: The world coordinates of this Game Object in pixels.Depending on where in the display list this Game Object is placed this value can differ from `position`, which contains the x/y coordinates relative to the Game Objects parent.

members.name: debug
members.description: A debug flag designed for use with `Game.enableStep`.

members.name: previousPosition
members.description: The position the Game Object was located in the previous frame.

members.name: previousRotation
members.description: The rotation the Game Object was in set to in the previous frame. Value is in radians.

members.name: renderOrderID
members.description: The render order ID is used internally by the renderer and Input Manager and should not be modified.This property is mostly used internally by the renderers, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: fresh
members.description: A Game Object is considered `fresh` if it has just been created or reset and is yet to receive a renderer transform update.This property is mostly used internally by the physics systems, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Game Object is that is pendingDestroy is flagged to have its destroy method called on the next logic update.You can set it directly to allow you to flag an object to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy an object from within one of its own callbacks such as with Buttons or other Input events.

members.name: _exists
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if this Game Object is processed by the core game loop.If this Game Object has a physics body it also controls if its physics body is updated or not.When `exists` is set to `false` it will remove its physics body from the physics world if it has one.It also toggles the `visible` property to false as well.Setting `exists` to true will add its physics body back in to the physics world, if it has one.It will also set the `visible` property to `true`.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle property is the rotation of the Game Object in *degrees* from its original orientation.Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees you can use the property `rotation` instead. Working in radians is slightly faster as it doesn't have to perform any calculations.

members.name: autoCull
members.description: A Game Object with `autoCull` set to true will check its bounds against the World Camera every frame.If it is not intersecting the Camera bounds at any point then it has its `renderable` property set to `false`.This keeps the Game Object alive and still processing updates, but forces it to skip the render step entirely.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: inCamera
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds intersect with the Game Camera bounds.Returns `true` if they do, otherwise `false` if fully outside of the Cameras bounds.

members.name: offsetX
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its x coordinate.This is the same as `width * anchor.x`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.x is not equal to zero.

members.name: offsetY
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its y coordinate.This is the same as `height * anchor.y`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.y is not equal to zero.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x - offsetX`.

members.name: right
members.description: The right coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x + width - offsetX`.

members.name: top
members.description: The y coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `y - offsetY`.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and height properties.This is the same as `y + height - offsetY`.

members.name: destroyPhase
members.description: As a Game Object runs through its destroy method this flag is set to true, and can be checked in any sub-systems or plugins it is being destroyed from.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Game Object that is "fixed" to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera during rendering.The values are adjusted at the rendering stage, overriding the Game Objects actual world position.The end result is that the Game Object will appear to be 'fixed' to the camera, regardless of where in the game worldthe camera is viewing. This is useful if for example this Game Object is a UI item that you wish to be visible at all times regardless where in the world the camera is.The offsets are stored in the `cameraOffset` property.Note that the `cameraOffset` values are in addition to any parent of this Game Object on the display list.Be careful not to set `fixedToCamera` on Game Objects which are in Groups that already have `fixedToCamera` enabled on them.

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: The x/y coordinate offset applied to the top-left of the camera that this Game Object will be drawn at if `fixedToCamera` is true.The values are relative to the top-left of the camera view and in addition to any parent of the Game Object on the display list.

members.name: input
members.description: The Input Handler for this Game Object.By default it is disabled. If you wish this Game Object to process input events you should enable it with: `inputEnabled = true`.After you have done this, this property will be a reference to the Phaser InputHandler.

members.name: inputEnabled
members.description: By default a Game Object won't process any input events. By setting `inputEnabled` to true a Phaser.InputHandler is createdfor this Game Object and it will then start to process click / touch events and more.You can then access the Input Handler via `this.input`.Note that Input related events are dispatched from `this.events`, i.e.: `events.onInputDown`.If you set this property to false it will stop the Input Handler from processing any more input events.

members.name: checkWorldBounds
members.description: If this is set to `true` the Game Object checks if it is within the World bounds each frame. When it is no longer intersecting the world bounds it dispatches the `onOutOfBounds` event.If it was *previously* out of bounds but is now intersecting the world bounds again it dispatches the `onEnterBounds` event.It also optionally kills the Game Object if `outOfBoundsKill` is `true`.When `checkWorldBounds` is enabled it forces the Game Object to calculate its full bounds every frame.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: outOfBoundsKill
members.description: If this and the `checkWorldBounds` property are both set to `true` then the `kill` method is called as soon as `inWorld` returns false.

members.name: _outOfBoundsFired
members.description: Internal state var.

members.name: inWorld
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds are within, or intersect at any point with the Game World bounds.

members.name: alive
members.description: A useful flag to control if the Game Object is alive or dead.This is set automatically by the Health components `damage` method should the object run out of health.Or you can toggle it via your game code.This property is mostly just provided to be used by your game - it doesn't effect rendering or logic updates.However you can use `Group.getFirstAlive` in conjunction with this property for fast object pooling and recycling.

members.name: lifespan
members.description: The lifespan allows you to give a Game Object a lifespan in milliseconds.Once the Game Object is 'born' you can set this to a positive value.It is automatically decremented by the millisecond equivalent of `game.time.physicsElapsed` each frame.When it reaches zero it will call the `kill` method.Very handy for particles, bullets, collectibles, or any other short-lived entity.

members.name: body
members.description: `body` is the Game Objects physics body. Once a Game Object is enabled for physics you access all associated properties and methods via it.By default Game Objects won't add themselves to any physics system and their `body` property will be `null`.To enable this Game Object for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(object, system)` where `object` is this objectand `system` is the Physics system you are using. If none is given it defaults to `Phaser.Physics.Arcade`.You can alternatively call `game.physics.arcade.enable(object)`, or add this Game Object to a physics enabled Group.Important: Enabling a Game Object for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set its `anchor` property to 0.5, so the physics body is centered on the Game Object.If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

classes.name: Phaser.Image
classes.description: An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events. This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

constructor.name: Image
constructor.description: An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events. This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The texture used by the Image during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Image is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Automatically called by World.preUpdate.

functions.name: setTexture
functions.description:
Sets the texture of the sprite. Be warned that this doesn't remove or destroy the previous
texture this Sprite was using.

parameters.name: texture
parameters.description: The PIXI texture that is displayed by the sprite

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: Call Texture.destroy on the current texture before replacing it with the new one?

functions.name: onTextureUpdate
functions.description: When the texture is updated, this event will fire to update the scale and frame

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the bounds of the Sprite as a rectangle. The bounds calculation takes the worldTransform into account.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: the transformation matrix of the sprite

returns.description: the framing rectangle

functions.name: _renderWebGL
functions.description: Renders the object using the WebGL renderer

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: - Optional matrix. If provided the Display Object will be rendered using this matrix, otherwise it will use its worldTransform.

functions.name: _renderCanvas
functions.description: Renders the object using the Canvas renderer

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: - Optional matrix. If provided the Display Object will be rendered using this matrix, otherwise it will use its worldTransform.

functions.name: addChild
functions.description: Adds a child to the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to add to the container

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: addChildAt
functions.description: Adds a child to the container at a specified index. If the index is out of bounds an error will be thrown

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to add

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to place the child in

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: swapChildren
functions.description: Swaps the position of 2 Display Objects within this container.

functions.name: getChildIndex
functions.description: Returns the index position of a child DisplayObject instance

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject instance to identify

returns.description: The index position of the child display object to identify

functions.name: setChildIndex
functions.description: Changes the position of an existing child in the display object container

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child DisplayObject instance for which you want to change the index number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The resulting index number for the child display object

functions.name: getChildAt
functions.description: Returns the child at the specified index

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child at the given index, if any.

functions.name: removeChild
functions.description: Removes a child from the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to remove

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildAt
functions.description: Removes a child from the specified index position.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildren
functions.description: Removes all children from this container that are within the begin and end indexes.

parameters.name: beginIndex
parameters.description: The beginning position. Default value is 0.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The ending position. Default value is size of the container.

functions.name: getLocalBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: setStageReference
functions.description: Sets the containers Stage reference. This is the Stage that this object, and all of its children, is connected to.

parameters.name: stage
parameters.description: the stage that the container will have as its current stage reference

functions.name: removeStageReference
functions.description: Removes the current stage reference from the container and all of its children.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description:
Destroy this DisplayObject.
Removes all references to transformCallbacks, its parent, the stage, filters, bounds, mask and cached Sprites.

functions.name: generateTexture
functions.description:
Useful function that returns a texture of the displayObject object that can then be used to create sprites
This can be quite useful if your displayObject is static / complicated and needs to be reused multiple times.

parameters.name: resolution
parameters.description: The resolution of the texture being generated

parameters.name: scaleMode
parameters.description: See {{#crossLink "PIXI/scaleModes:property"}}PIXI.scaleModes{{/crossLink}} for possible values

parameters.name: renderer
parameters.description: The renderer used to generate the texture.

returns.description: a texture of the graphics object

functions.name: updateCache
functions.description: Generates and updates the cached sprite for this object.

functions.name: toGlobal
functions.description: Calculates the global position of the display object

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The world origin to calculate from

returns.description: A point object representing the position of this object

functions.name: toLocal
functions.description: Calculates the local position of the display object relative to another point

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The world origin to calculate from

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to calculate the global position from

returns.description: A point object representing the position of this object

functions.name: _renderCachedSprite
functions.description: Internal method.

parameters.name: renderSession
parameters.description: The render session

functions.name: _generateCachedSprite
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: _destroyCachedSprite
functions.description: Destroys the cached sprite.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Override this method in your own custom objects to handle any update requirements.It is called immediately after `preUpdate` and before `postUpdate`.Remember if this Game Object has any children you should call update on those too.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method called by the World postUpdate cycle.

functions.name: play
functions.description: Plays an Animation.The animation should have previously been created via `animations.add`.If the animation is already playing calling this again won't do anything.If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself or via `AnimationManager.stop`.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump". Must have been previously created via 'AnimationManager.add'.

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.description: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.description: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.description: A reference to playing Animation.

functions.name: bringToTop
functions.description: Brings this Game Object to the top of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render over the top of any old child in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will bring it to the top of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: sendToBack
functions.description: Sends this Game Object to the bottom of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render below all other children in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will send it to the bottom of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: Moves this Game Object up one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the top of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object up within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: Moves this Game Object down one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the bottom of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object down within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: crop
functions.description: Crop allows you to crop the texture being used to display this Game Object.Setting a crop rectangle modifies the core texture frame. The Game Object width and height properties will be adjusted accordingly.Cropping takes place from the top-left and can be modified in real-time either by providing an updated rectangle object to this method,or by modifying `cropRect` property directly and then calling `updateCrop`.The rectangle object given to this method can be either a `Phaser.Rectangle` or any other object so long as it has public `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `right` and `bottom` properties.A reference to the rectangle is stored in `cropRect` unless the `copy` parameter is `true`, in which case the values are duplicated to a local object.

parameters.name: rect
parameters.description: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.description: If false `cropRect` will be stored as a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Phaser Rectangle object stored in cropRect.

functions.name: updateCrop
functions.description: If you have set a crop rectangle on this Game Object via `crop` and since modified the `cropRect` property,or the rectangle it references, then you need to update the crop frame by calling this method.

functions.name: revive
functions.description: Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: kill
functions.description: Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool, it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: loadTexture
functions.description: Changes the base texture the Game Object is using. The old texture is removed and the new one is referenced or fetched from the Cache.If your Game Object is using a frame from a texture atlas and you just wish to change to another frame, then see the `frame` or `frameName` properties instead.You should only use `loadTexture` if you want to replace the base texture entirely.Calling this method causes a WebGL texture update, so use sparingly or in low-intensity portions of your game, or if you know the new texture is already on the GPU.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

parameters.name: stopAnimation
parameters.description: If an animation is already playing on this Sprite you can choose to stop it or let it carry on playing.

functions.name: setFrame
functions.description: Sets the texture frame the Game Object uses for rendering.This is primarily an internal method used by `loadTexture`, but is exposed for the use of plugins and custom classes.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The Frame to be used by the texture.

functions.name: resizeFrame
functions.description: Resizes the Frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.You shouldn't normally need to ever call this, but in the case of special texture types such as Video or BitmapDatait can be useful to adjust the dimensions directly in this way.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent texture object that caused the resize, i.e. a Phaser.Video object.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The new width of the texture.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The new height of the texture.

functions.name: resetFrame
functions.description: Resets the texture frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.

functions.name: overlap
functions.description: Checks to see if the bounds of this Game Object overlaps with the bounds of the given Display Object, which can be a Sprite, Image, TileSprite or anything that extends those such as Button or provides a `getBounds` method and result.This check ignores the `hitArea` property if set and runs a `getBounds` comparison on both objects to determine the result.Therefore it's relatively expensive to use in large quantities, i.e. with lots of Sprites at a high frequency.It should be fine for low-volume testing where physics isn't required.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to check against.

returns.description: True if the bounds of this Game Object intersects at any point with the bounds of the given display object.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: anchor
members.description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

members.name: texture
members.description: The texture that the sprite is using

members.name: _width
members.description: The width of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: _height
members.description: The height of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: tint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: cachedTint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: tintedTexture
members.description: A canvas that contains the tinted version of the Sprite (in Canvas mode, WebGL doesn't populate this)

members.name: blendMode
members.description:
The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

Warning: You cannot have a blend mode and a filter active on the same Sprite. Doing so will render the sprite invisible.

members.name: shader
members.description: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: position
members.description: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: scale
members.description: The scale factor of the object.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

members.name: pivot
members.description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

members.name: rotation
members.description: The rotation of the object in radians.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The opacity of the object.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility of the object.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description: Can this object be rendered

members.name: parent
members.description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

members.name: stage
members.description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

members.name: worldTransform
members.description: [read-only] Current transform of the object based on world (parent) factors

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: _sr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: _cr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: filterArea
members.description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

members.name: _bounds
members.description: The original, cached bounds of the object

members.name: _currentBounds
members.description: The most up-to-date bounds of the object

members.name: _mask
members.description: The original, cached mask of the object

members.name: _cacheAsBitmap
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: _cacheIsDirty
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.
In PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.
To remove a mask, set this property to null.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for the displayObject.
IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the Canvas renderer.

To remove filters simply set this property to 'null'.

You cannot have a filter and a multiply blend mode active at the same time. Setting a filter will reset
