members.name: textureDebug
members.description:
If enabled a green rectangle will be drawn behind the generated tiling texture, allowing you to visually
debug the texture being used.

members.name: blendMode
members.description: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite

members.name: canvasBuffer
members.description: The CanvasBuffer object that the tiled texture is drawn to.

members.name: tilingTexture
members.description: An internal Texture object that holds the tiling texture that was generated from TilingSprite.texture.

members.name: tilePattern
members.description: The Context fill pattern that is used to draw the TilingSprite in Canvas mode only (will be null in WebGL).

members.name: refreshTexture
members.description:
If true the TilingSprite will run generateTexture on its **next** render pass.
This is set by the likes of Phaser.LoadTexture.setFrame.

members.name: anchor
members.description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

members.name: texture
members.description: The texture that the sprite is using

members.name: _width
members.description: The width of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: _height
members.description: The height of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: cachedTint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: tintedTexture
members.description: A canvas that contains the tinted version of the Sprite (in Canvas mode, WebGL doesn't populate this)

members.name: shader
members.description: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: position
members.description: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: scale
members.description: The scale factor of the object.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

members.name: pivot
members.description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

members.name: rotation
members.description: The rotation of the object in radians.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The opacity of the object.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility of the object.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: parent
members.description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

members.name: stage
members.description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

members.name: worldTransform
members.description: [read-only] Current transform of the object based on world (parent) factors

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: _sr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: _cr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: filterArea
members.description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

members.name: _bounds
members.description: The original, cached bounds of the object

members.name: _currentBounds
members.description: The most up-to-date bounds of the object

members.name: _mask
members.description: The original, cached mask of the object

members.name: _cacheAsBitmap
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: _cacheIsDirty
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.
In PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.
To remove a mask, set this property to null.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for the displayObject.
IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the Canvas renderer.

To remove filters simply set this property to 'null'.

You cannot have a filter and a multiply blend mode active at the same time. Setting a filter will reset
this objects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.
This basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.
To remove simply set this property to 'null'

members.name: x
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: y
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A user defined name given to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, it is meant as a game level property.

members.name: components
members.description: The components this Game Object has installed.

members.name: z
members.description: The z depth of this Game Object within its parent Group.No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.This value is adjusted automatically whenever the Group hierarchy changes.

members.name: events
members.description: All Phaser Game Objects have an Events class which contains all of the events that are dispatched when certain things happen to thisGame Object, or any of its components.

members.name: animations
members.description: If the Game Object is enabled for animation (such as a Phaser.Sprite) this is a reference to its AnimationManager instance.Through it you can create, play, pause and stop animations.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the image or texture used by this Game Object during rendering.If it is a string it's the string used to retrieve the texture from the Phaser Image Cache.It can also be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.If a Game Object is created without a key it is automatically assigned the key `__default` which is a 32x32 transparent PNG stored within the Cache.If a Game Object is given a key which doesn't exist in the Image Cache it is re-assigned the key `__missing` which is a 32x32 PNG of a green box with a line through it.

members.name: world
members.description: The world coordinates of this Game Object in pixels.Depending on where in the display list this Game Object is placed this value can differ from `position`, which contains the x/y coordinates relative to the Game Objects parent.

members.name: debug
members.description: A debug flag designed for use with `Game.enableStep`.

members.name: previousPosition
members.description: The position the Game Object was located in the previous frame.

members.name: previousRotation
members.description: The rotation the Game Object was in set to in the previous frame. Value is in radians.

members.name: renderOrderID
members.description: The render order ID is used internally by the renderer and Input Manager and should not be modified.This property is mostly used internally by the renderers, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: fresh
members.description: A Game Object is considered `fresh` if it has just been created or reset and is yet to receive a renderer transform update.This property is mostly used internally by the physics systems, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Game Object is that is pendingDestroy is flagged to have its destroy method called on the next logic update.You can set it directly to allow you to flag an object to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy an object from within one of its own callbacks such as with Buttons or other Input events.

members.name: _exists
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if this Game Object is processed by the core game loop.If this Game Object has a physics body it also controls if its physics body is updated or not.When `exists` is set to `false` it will remove its physics body from the physics world if it has one.It also toggles the `visible` property to false as well.Setting `exists` to true will add its physics body back in to the physics world, if it has one.It will also set the `visible` property to `true`.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle property is the rotation of the Game Object in *degrees* from its original orientation.Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees you can use the property `rotation` instead. Working in radians is slightly faster as it doesn't have to perform any calculations.

members.name: autoCull
members.description: A Game Object with `autoCull` set to true will check its bounds against the World Camera every frame.If it is not intersecting the Camera bounds at any point then it has its `renderable` property set to `false`.This keeps the Game Object alive and still processing updates, but forces it to skip the render step entirely.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: inCamera
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds intersect with the Game Camera bounds.Returns `true` if they do, otherwise `false` if fully outside of the Cameras bounds.

members.name: offsetX
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its x coordinate.This is the same as `width * anchor.x`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.x is not equal to zero.

members.name: offsetY
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its y coordinate.This is the same as `height * anchor.y`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.y is not equal to zero.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x - offsetX`.

members.name: right
members.description: The right coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x + width - offsetX`.

members.name: top
members.description: The y coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `y - offsetY`.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and height properties.This is the same as `y + height - offsetY`.

members.name: destroyPhase
members.description: As a Game Object runs through its destroy method this flag is set to true, and can be checked in any sub-systems or plugins it is being destroyed from.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Game Object that is "fixed" to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera during rendering.The values are adjusted at the rendering stage, overriding the Game Objects actual world position.The end result is that the Game Object will appear to be 'fixed' to the camera, regardless of where in the game worldthe camera is viewing. This is useful if for example this Game Object is a UI item that you wish to be visible at all times regardless where in the world the camera is.The offsets are stored in the `cameraOffset` property.Note that the `cameraOffset` values are in addition to any parent of this Game Object on the display list.Be careful not to set `fixedToCamera` on Game Objects which are in Groups that already have `fixedToCamera` enabled on them.

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: The x/y coordinate offset applied to the top-left of the camera that this Game Object will be drawn at if `fixedToCamera` is true.The values are relative to the top-left of the camera view and in addition to any parent of the Game Object on the display list.

members.name: health
members.description: The Game Objects health value. This is a handy property for setting and manipulating health on a Game Object.It can be used in combination with the `damage` method or modified directly.

members.name: maxHealth
members.description: The Game Objects maximum health value. This works in combination with the `heal` method to ensurethe health value never exceeds the maximum.

members.name: damage
members.description: Damages the Game Object. This removes the given amount of health from the `health` property.If health is taken below or is equal to zero then the `kill` method is called.

members.name: heal
members.description: Heal the Game Object. This adds the given amount of health to the `health` property.

members.name: input
members.description: The Input Handler for this Game Object.By default it is disabled. If you wish this Game Object to process input events you should enable it with: `inputEnabled = true`.After you have done this, this property will be a reference to the Phaser InputHandler.

members.name: inputEnabled
members.description: By default a Game Object won't process any input events. By setting `inputEnabled` to true a Phaser.InputHandler is createdfor this Game Object and it will then start to process click / touch events and more.You can then access the Input Handler via `this.input`.Note that Input related events are dispatched from `this.events`, i.e.: `events.onInputDown`.If you set this property to false it will stop the Input Handler from processing any more input events.

members.name: checkWorldBounds
members.description: If this is set to `true` the Game Object checks if it is within the World bounds each frame. When it is no longer intersecting the world bounds it dispatches the `onOutOfBounds` event.If it was *previously* out of bounds but is now intersecting the world bounds again it dispatches the `onEnterBounds` event.It also optionally kills the Game Object if `outOfBoundsKill` is `true`.When `checkWorldBounds` is enabled it forces the Game Object to calculate its full bounds every frame.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: outOfBoundsKill
members.description: If this and the `checkWorldBounds` property are both set to `true` then the `kill` method is called as soon as `inWorld` returns false.

members.name: _outOfBoundsFired
members.description: Internal state var.

members.name: inWorld
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds are within, or intersect at any point with the Game World bounds.

members.name: alive
members.description: A useful flag to control if the Game Object is alive or dead.This is set automatically by the Health components `damage` method should the object run out of health.Or you can toggle it via your game code.This property is mostly just provided to be used by your game - it doesn't effect rendering or logic updates.However you can use `Group.getFirstAlive` in conjunction with this property for fast object pooling and recycling.

members.name: lifespan
members.description: The lifespan allows you to give a Game Object a lifespan in milliseconds.Once the Game Object is 'born' you can set this to a positive value.It is automatically decremented by the millisecond equivalent of `game.time.physicsElapsed` each frame.When it reaches zero it will call the `kill` method.Very handy for particles, bullets, collectibles, or any other short-lived entity.

members.name: customRender
members.description: Does this texture require a custom render call? (as set by BitmapData, Video, etc)

members.name: _frame
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: frame
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame index of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frame` to the index of the new frame in the sprite sheet you wish this Game Object to use,for example: `player.frame = 4`.If the frame index given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture.If you are using a texture atlas then you should use the `frameName` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: frameName
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame name of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frameName` to the name of the new frame in the texture atlas you wish this Game Object to use, for example: `player.frameName = "idle"`.If the frame name given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture and throw a console warning.If you are using a sprite sheet then you should use the `frame` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: body
members.description: `body` is the Game Objects physics body. Once a Game Object is enabled for physics you access all associated properties and methods via it.By default Game Objects won't add themselves to any physics system and their `body` property will be `null`.To enable this Game Object for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(object, system)` where `object` is this objectand `system` is the Physics system you are using. If none is given it defaults to `Phaser.Physics.Arcade`.You can alternatively call `game.physics.arcade.enable(object)`, or add this Game Object to a physics enabled Group.Important: Enabling a Game Object for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set its `anchor` property to 0.5, so the physics body is centered on the Game Object.If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

members.name: smoothed
members.description: Enable or disable texture smoothing for this Game Object.It only takes effect if the Game Object is using an image based texture.Smoothing is enabled by default.

classes.name: Phaser.Video
classes.description: A Video object that takes a previously loaded Video from the Phaser Cache and handles playback of it.Alternatively it takes a getUserMedia feed from an active webcam and streams the contents of that tothe Video instead (see `startMediaStream` method)The video can then be applied to a Sprite as a texture. If multiple Sprites share the same Video texture and playbackchanges (i.e. you pause the video, or seek to a new time) then this change will be seen across all Sprites simultaneously.Due to a bug in IE11 you cannot play a video texture to a Sprite in WebGL. For IE11 force Canvas mode.If you need each Sprite to be able to play a video fully independently then you will need one Video object per Sprite.Please understand the obvious performance implications of doing this, and the memory required to hold videos in RAM.On some mobile browsers such as iOS Safari, you cannot play a video until the user has explicitly touched the screen.This works in the same way as audio unlocking. Phaser will handle the touch unlocking for you, however unlike with audioit's worth noting that every single Video needs to be touch unlocked, not just the first one. You can use the `changeSource`method to try and work around this limitation, but see the method help for details.Small screen devices, especially iPod and iPhone will launch the video in its own native video player, outside of the Safari browser. There is no way to avoid this, it's a device imposed limitation.

constructor.name: Video
constructor.description: A Video object that takes a previously loaded Video from the Phaser Cache and handles playback of it.Alternatively it takes a getUserMedia feed from an active webcam and streams the contents of that tothe Video instead (see `startMediaStream` method)The video can then be applied to a Sprite as a texture. If multiple Sprites share the same Video texture and playbackchanges (i.e. you pause the video, or seek to a new time) then this change will be seen across all Sprites simultaneously.Due to a bug in IE11 you cannot play a video texture to a Sprite in WebGL. For IE11 force Canvas mode.If you need each Sprite to be able to play a video fully independently then you will need one Video object per Sprite.Please understand the obvious performance implications of doing this, and the memory required to hold videos in RAM.On some mobile browsers such as iOS Safari, you cannot play a video until the user has explicitly touched the screen.This works in the same way as audio unlocking. Phaser will handle the touch unlocking for you, however unlike with audioit's worth noting that every single Video needs to be touch unlocked, not just the first one. You can use the `changeSource`method to try and work around this limitation, but see the method help for details.Small screen devices, especially iPod and iPhone will launch the video in its own native video player, outside of the Safari browser. There is no way to avoid this, it's a device imposed limitation.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the video file in the Phaser.Cache that this Video object will play. Set to `null` or leave undefined if you wish to use a webcam as the source. See `startMediaStream` to start webcam capture.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: If the video hasn't been loaded then you can provide a full URL to the file here (make sure to set key to null)

functions.name: connectToMediaStream
functions.description: Connects to an external media stream for the webcam, rather than using a local one.

parameters.name: video
parameters.description: The HTML Video Element that the stream uses.

parameters.name: stream
parameters.description: The Video Stream data.

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: startMediaStream
functions.description: Instead of playing a video file this method allows you to stream video data from an attached webcam.As soon as this method is called the user will be prompted by their browser to "Allow" access to the webcam.If they allow it the webcam feed is directed to this Video. Call `Video.play` to start the stream.If they block the webcam the onError signal will be dispatched containing the NavigatorUserMediaErroror MediaStreamError event.You can optionally set a width and height for the stream. If set the input will be cropped to these dimensions.If not given then as soon as the stream has enough data the video dimensions will be changed to match the webcam device.You can listen for this with the onChangeSource signal.

parameters.name: captureAudio
parameters.description: Controls if audio should be captured along with video in the video stream.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width is used to create the video stream. If not provided the video width will be set to the width of the webcam input source.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height is used to create the video stream. If not provided the video height will be set to the height of the webcam input source.

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining or false if the device doesn't support getUserMedia.

functions.name: createVideoFromBlob
functions.description: Creates a new Video element from the given Blob. The Blob must contain the video data in the correct encoded format.This method is typically called by the Phaser.Loader and Phaser.Cache for you, but is exposed publicly for convenience.

parameters.name: blob
parameters.description: The Blob containing the video data: `Blob([new Uint8Array(data)])`

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: createVideoFromURL
functions.description: Creates a new Video element from the given URL.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL of the video.

parameters.name: autoplay
parameters.description: Automatically start the video?

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: updateTexture
functions.description: Called automatically if the video source changes and updates the internal texture dimensions.Then dispatches the onChangeSource signal.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event which triggered the texture update.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The new width of the video. If undefined `video.videoWidth` is used.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The new height of the video. If undefined `video.videoHeight` is used.

functions.name: complete
functions.description: Called when the video completes playback (reaches and ended state).Dispatches the Video.onComplete signal.

functions.name: play
functions.description: Starts this video playing if it's not already doing so.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the video loop automatically when it reaches the end? Please note that at present some browsers (i.e. Chrome) do not support *seamless* video looping.

parameters.name: playbackRate
parameters.description: The playback rate of the video. 1 is normal speed, 2 is x2 speed, and so on. You cannot set a negative playback rate.

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: playHandler
functions.description: Called when the video starts to play. Updates the texture.

functions.name: stop
functions.description: Stops the video playing.This removes all locally set signals.If you only wish to pause playback of the video, to resume at a later time, use `Video.paused = true` instead.If the video hasn't finished downloading calling `Video.stop` will not abort the download. To do that you need to call `Video.destroy` instead.If you are using a video stream from a webcam then calling Stop will disconnect the MediaStream session and disable the webcam.

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: add
functions.description: Updates the given Display Objects so they use this Video as their texture.This will replace any texture they will currently have set.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: Either a single Sprite/Image or an Array of Sprites/Images.

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: addToWorld
functions.description: Creates a new Phaser.Image object, assigns this Video to be its texture, adds it to the world then returns it.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to place the Image at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to place the Image at.

parameters.name: anchorX
parameters.description: Set the x anchor point of the Image. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.

parameters.name: anchorY
parameters.description: Set the y anchor point of the Image. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.

parameters.name: scaleX
parameters.description: The horizontal scale factor of the Image. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.

parameters.name: scaleY
parameters.description: The vertical scale factor of the Image. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.

returns.description: The newly added Image object.

functions.name: render
functions.description: If the game is running in WebGL this will push the texture up to the GPU if it's dirty.This is called automatically if the Video is being used by a Sprite, otherwise you need to remember to call it in your render function.If you wish to suppress this functionality set Video.disableTextureUpload to `true`.

functions.name: setMute
functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.mute setter.

functions.name: unsetMute
functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.mute setter.

functions.name: setPause
functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.paused setter.

functions.name: setResume
functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.paused setter.

functions.name: changeSource
functions.description: On some mobile browsers you cannot play a video until the user has explicitly touched the video to allow it.Phaser handles this via the `setTouchLock` method. However if you have 3 different videos, maybe an "Intro", "Start" and "Game Over"split into three different Video objects, then you will need the user to touch-unlock every single one of them.You can avoid this by using just one Video object and simply changing the video source. Once a Video element is unlocked it remainsunlocked, even if the source changes. So you can use this to your benefit to avoid forcing the user to 'touch' the video yet again.As you'd expect there are limitations. So far we've found that the videos need to be in the same encoding format and bitrate.This method will automatically handle a change in video dimensions, but if you try swapping to a different bitrate we've found itcannot render the new video on iOS (desktop browsers cope better).When the video source is changed the video file is requested over the network. Listen for the `onChangeSource` signal to knowwhen the new video has downloaded enough content to be able to be played. Previous settings such as the volume and loop stateare adopted automatically by the new video.

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: The new URL to change the video.src to.

parameters.name: autoplay
parameters.description: Should the video play automatically after the source has been updated?

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: checkVideoProgress
functions.description: Internal callback that monitors the download progress of a video after changing its source.

functions.name: setTouchLock
functions.description: Sets the Input Manager touch callback to be Video.unlock.Required for mobile video unlocking. Mostly just used internally.

functions.name: unlock
functions.description: Enables the video on mobile devices, usually after the first touch.If the SoundManager hasn't been unlocked then this will automatically unlock that as well.Only one video can be pending unlock at any one time.

functions.name: grab
functions.description: Grabs the current frame from the Video or Video Stream and renders it to the Video.snapshot BitmapData.You can optionally set if the BitmapData should be cleared or not, the alpha and the blend mode of the draw.If you need more advanced control over the grabbing them call `Video.snapshot.copy` directly with the same parameters as BitmapData.copy.

parameters.name: clear
parameters.description: Should the BitmapData be cleared before the Video is grabbed? Unless you are using alpha or a blend mode you can usually leave this set to false.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha that will be set on the video before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.

parameters.name: blendMode
parameters.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.

returns.description: A reference to the Video.snapshot BitmapData object for further method chaining.

functions.name: removeVideoElement
functions.description: Removes the Video element from the DOM by calling parentNode.removeChild on itself.Also removes the autoplay and src attributes and nulls the reference.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys the Video object. This calls `Video.stop` and then `Video.removeVideoElement`.If any Sprites are using this Video as their texture it is up to you to manage those.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running game.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the Video in the Cache, if stored there. Will be `null` if this Video is using the webcam instead.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the video in pixels.

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the video in pixels.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: disableTextureUpload
members.description: If true this video will never send its image data to the GPU when its dirty flag is true. This only applies in WebGL.

members.name: touchLocked
members.description: true if this video is currently locked awaiting a touch event. This happens on some mobile devices, such as iOS.

members.name: onPlay
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the Video starts to play. It sends 3 parameters: a reference to the Video object, if the video is set to loop or not and the playback rate.

members.name: onChangeSource
members.description: This signal is dispatched if the Video source is changed. It sends 3 parameters: a reference to the Video object and the new width and height of the new video source.

members.name: onComplete
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the Video completes playback, i.e. enters an 'ended' state. Videos set to loop will never dispatch this signal.

members.name: onAccess
members.description: This signal is dispatched if the user allows access to their webcam.

members.name: onError
members.description: This signal is dispatched if an error occurs either getting permission to use the webcam (for a Video Stream) or when trying to play back a video file.

members.name: onTimeout
members.description: This signal is dispatched if when asking for permission to use the webcam no response is given within a the Video.timeout limit.This may be because the user has picked `Not now` in the permissions window, or there is a delay in establishing the LocalMediaStream.

members.name: timeout
members.description: The amount of ms allowed to elapsed before the Video.onTimeout signal is dispatched while waiting for webcam access.

members.name: _timeOutID
members.description: setTimeout ID.

members.name: video
members.description: The HTML Video Element that is added to the document.

members.name: videoStream
members.description: The Video Stream data. Only set if this Video is streaming from the webcam via `startMediaStream`.

members.name: isStreaming
members.description: Is there a streaming video source? I.e. from a webcam.

members.name: retryLimit
members.description: When starting playback of a video Phaser will monitor its readyState using a setTimeout call.The setTimeout happens once every `Video.retryInterval` ms. It will carry on monitoring the videostate in this manner until the `retryLimit` is reached and then abort.

members.name: retry
members.description: The current retry attempt.

members.name: retryInterval
members.description: The number of ms between each retry at monitoring the status of a downloading video.

members.name: _retryID
members.description: The callback ID of the retry setTimeout.

members.name: _codeMuted
members.description: Internal mute tracking var.

members.name: _muted
members.description: Internal mute tracking var.

members.name: _codePaused
members.description: Internal paused tracking var.

members.name: _paused
members.description: Internal paused tracking var.

members.name: _pending
members.description: Internal var tracking play pending.

members.name: _autoplay
members.description: Internal var tracking autoplay when changing source.

members.name: texture
members.description: The PIXI.Texture.

members.name: textureFrame
members.description: The Frame this video uses for rendering.

members.name: snapshot
members.description: A snapshot grabbed from the video. This is initially black. Populate it by calling Video.grab().When called the BitmapData is updated with a grab taken from the current video playing or active video stream.If Phaser has been compiled without BitmapData support this property will always be `null`.

members.name: mute
members.description: Gets or sets the muted state of the Video.

members.name: paused
members.description: Gets or sets the paused state of the Video.If the video is still touch locked (such as on iOS devices) this call has no effect.

members.name: volume
members.description: Gets or sets the volume of the Video, a value between 0 and 1. The value given is clamped to the range 0 to 1.

members.name: playbackRate
members.description: Gets or sets the playback rate of the Video. This is the speed at which the video is playing.

members.name: loop
members.description: Gets or sets if the Video is set to loop.Please note that at present some browsers (i.e. Chrome) do not support *seamless* video looping.If the video isn't yet set this will always return false.

members.name: playing
members.description: True if the video is currently playing (and not paused or ended), otherwise false.

classes.name: Phaser.Circle
classes.description: Creates a new Circle object with the center coordinate specified by the x and y parameters and the diameter specified by the diameter parameter.If you call this function without parameters, a circle with x, y, diameter and radius properties set to 0 is created.

constructor.name: Circle
constructor.description: Creates a new Circle object with the center coordinate specified by the x and y parameters and the diameter specified by the diameter parameter.If you call this function without parameters, a circle with x, y, diameter and radius properties set to 0 is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: diameter
parameters.description: The diameter of the circle.

functions.name: circumference
functions.description: The circumference of the circle.

returns.description: The circumference of the circle.

functions.name: random
functions.description: Returns a uniformly distributed random point from anywhere within this Circle.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point, or any object with public x/y properties, that the values will be set in.    If no object is provided a new Phaser.Point object will be created. In high performance areas avoid this by re-using an existing object.

returns.description: An object containing the random point in its `x` and `y` properties.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the framing rectangle of the circle as a Phaser.Rectangle object.

returns.description: The bounds of the Circle.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets the members of Circle to the specified values.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: diameter
parameters.description: The diameter of the circle.

returns.description: This circle object.

functions.name: copyFrom
functions.description: Copies the x, y and diameter properties from any given object to this Circle.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The object to copy from.

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: copyTo
functions.description: Copies the x, y and diameter properties from this Circle to any given object.

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The object to copy to.

returns.description: This dest object.

functions.name: distance
functions.description: Returns the distance from the center of the Circle object to the given object(can be Circle, Point or anything with x/y properties)

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The target object. Must have visible x and y properties that represent the center of the object.

parameters.name: round
parameters.description: Round the distance to the nearest integer.

returns.description: The distance between this Point object and the destination Point object.

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Returns a new Circle object with the same values for the x, y, width, and height properties as this Circle object.

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: Optional Circle object. If given the values will be set into the object, otherwise a brand new Circle object will be created and returned.

returns.description: The cloned Circle object.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Return true if the given x/y coordinates are within this Circle object.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The X value of the coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The Y value of the coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the coordinates are within this circle, otherwise false.

functions.name: circumferencePoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object containing the coordinates of a point on the circumference of the Circle based on the given angle.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to return the point from.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: An optional Point object to put the result in to. If none specified a new Point object will be created.

returns.description: The Point object holding the result.

functions.name: offset
functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Circle object, as determined by its center coordinate, by the specified amounts.

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: Moves the x value of the Circle object by this amount.

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: Moves the y value of the Circle object by this amount.

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: offsetPoint
functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Circle object using a Point object as a parameter. This method is similar to the Circle.offset() method, except that it takes a Point object as a parameter.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: A Point object to use to offset this Circle object (or any valid object with exposed x and y properties).

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: toString
functions.description: Returns a string representation of this object.

returns.description: a string representation of the instance.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Return true if the given x/y coordinates are within the Circle object.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The Circle to be checked.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The X value of the coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The Y value of the coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the coordinates are within this circle, otherwise false.

functions.name: equals
functions.description: Determines whether the two Circle objects match. This method compares the x, y and diameter properties.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Circle object.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Circle object.

returns.description: A value of true if the object has exactly the same values for the x, y and diameter properties as this Circle object; otherwise false.

functions.name: intersects

parameters.name: a

functions.name: circumferencePoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object containing the coordinates of a point on the circumference of the Circle based on the given angle.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to return the point from.

parameters.name: asDegrees

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: An optional Point object to put the result in to. If none specified a new Point object will be created.

functions.description: Checks if the given Circle and Rectangle objects intersect.

parameters.name: c
parameters.description: The Circle object to test.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The Rectangle object to test.

returns.description: True if the two objects intersect, otherwise false.

members.name: x
members.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

members.name: y
members.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

members.name: _diameter
members.description: The diameter of the circle.

members.name: _radius
members.description: The radius of the circle.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: diameter
members.description: The largest distance between any two points on the circle. The same as the radius * 2. Gets or sets the diameter of the circle.

members.name: radius
members.description: The length of a line extending from the center of the circle to any point on the circle itself. The same as half the diameter. Gets or sets the radius of the circle.

members.name: left
members.description: The x coordinate of the leftmost point of the circle. Changing the left property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties. However it does affect the diameter, whereas changing the x value does not affect the diameter property.

members.name: right
members.description: The x coordinate of the rightmost point of the circle. Changing the right property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties. However it does affect the diameter, whereas changing the x value does not affect the diameter property. Gets or sets the value of the rightmost point of the circle.

members.name: top
members.description: The sum of the y minus the radius property. Changing the top property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties, but does change the diameter. Gets or sets the top of the circle.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and radius properties. Changing the bottom property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties, but does change the diameter. Gets or sets the bottom of the circle.

members.name: area
members.description: The area of this Circle.

members.name: empty
members.description: Determines whether or not this Circle object is empty. Will return a value of true if the Circle objects diameter is less than or equal to 0; otherwise false.If set to true it will reset all of the Circle objects properties to 0. A Circle object is empty if its diameter is less than or equal to 0. Gets or sets the empty state of the circle.

members.name: x
members.description: The X coordinate of the upper-left corner of the framing rectangle of this ellipse.

members.description: The overall width of this ellipse.

members.description: The overall height of this ellipse.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of the Ellipse. The same as the X coordinate.

members.name: right
members.description: The x coordinate of the rightmost point of the Ellipse. Changing the right property of an Ellipse object has no effect on the x property, but does adjust the width. Gets or sets the value of the rightmost point of the ellipse.

members.name: top
members.description: The top of the Ellipse. The same as its y property. Gets or sets the top of the ellipse.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and height properties. Changing the bottom property of an Ellipse doesn't adjust the y property, but does change the height. Gets or sets the bottom of the ellipse.

members.name: empty
members.description: Determines whether or not this Ellipse object is empty. Will return a value of true if the Ellipse objects dimensions are less than or equal to 0; otherwise false.If set to true it will reset all of the Ellipse objects properties to 0. An Ellipse object is empty if its width or height is less than or equal to 0. Gets or sets the empty state of the ellipse.

classes.name: Phaser.Line
classes.description: Creates a new Line object with a start and an end point.

constructor.name: Line
constructor.description: Creates a new Line object with a start and an end point.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets the components of the Line to the specified values.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: fromSprite
functions.description: Sets the line to match the x/y coordinates of the two given sprites.Can optionally be calculated from their center coordinates.

parameters.name: startSprite
parameters.description: The coordinates of this Sprite will be set to the Line.start point.

parameters.name: endSprite
parameters.description: The coordinates of this Sprite will be set to the Line.start point.

parameters.name: useCenter
parameters.description: If true it will use startSprite.center.x, if false startSprite.x. Note that Sprites don't have a center property by default, so only enable if you've over-ridden your Sprite with a custom class.

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: fromAngle
functions.description: Sets this line to start at the given `x` and `y` coordinates and for the segment to extend at `angle` for the given `length`.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the line in radians.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The length of the line in pixels.

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: rotate
functions.description: Rotates the line by the amount specified in `angle`.Rotation takes place from the center of the line.If you wish to rotate around a different point see Line.rotateAround.If you wish to rotate the ends of the Line then see Line.start.rotate or Line.end.rotate.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the line by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: rotateAround
functions.description: Rotates the line by the amount specified in `angle`.Rotation takes place around the coordinates given.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the line by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: intersects
functions.description: Checks for intersection between this line and another Line.If asSegment is true it will check for segment intersection. If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: reflect
functions.description: Returns the reflected angle between two lines.This is the outgoing angle based on the angle of this line and the normalAngle of the given line.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line to reflect off this line.

returns.description: The reflected angle in radians.

functions.name: midPoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object where the x and y values correspond to the center (or midpoint) of the Line segment.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point object into which the result will be populated. If not given a new Point object is created.

returns.description: A Phaser.Point object with the x and y values set to the center of the line segment.

functions.name: centerOn
functions.description: Centers this Line on the given coordinates.The line is centered by positioning the start and end points so that the lines midpoint matchesthe coordinates given.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to center the line on.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to center the line on.

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: pointOnLine
functions.description: Tests if the given coordinates fall on this line. See pointOnSegment to test against just the line segment.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

returns.description: True if the point is on the line, false if not.

functions.name: pointOnSegment
functions.description: Tests if the given coordinates fall on this line and within the segment. See pointOnLine to test against just the line.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

returns.description: True if the point is on the line and segment, false if not.

functions.name: random
functions.description: Picks a random point from anywhere on the Line segment and returns it.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point, or any object with public x/y properties, that the values will be set in.    If no object is provided a new Phaser.Point object will be created. In high performance areas avoid this by re-using an object.

returns.description: An object containing the random point in its `x` and `y` properties.

functions.name: coordinatesOnLine
functions.description: Using Bresenham's line algorithm this will return an array of all coordinates on this line.The start and end points are rounded before this runs as the algorithm works on integers.

parameters.name: stepRate
parameters.description: How many steps will we return? 1 = every coordinate on the line, 2 = every other coordinate, etc.

parameters.name: results
parameters.description: The array to store the results in. If not provided a new one will be generated.

returns.description: An array of coordinates.

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Returns a new Line object with the same values for the start and end properties as this Line object.

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: Optional Line object. If given the values will be set into the object, otherwise a brand new Line object will be created and returned.

returns.description: The cloned Line object.

functions.name: intersectsPoints
functions.description: Checks for intersection between two lines as defined by the given start and end points.If asSegment is true it will check for line segment intersection. If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.Adapted from code by Keith Hair

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The start of the first Line to be checked.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The end of the first line to be checked.

parameters.name: e
parameters.description: The start of the second Line to be checked.

parameters.name: f
parameters.description: The end of the second line to be checked.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: intersects
functions.description: Checks for intersection between two lines.If asSegment is true it will check for segment intersection.If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.Adapted from code by Keith Hair

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Line to be checked.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Line to be checked.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: reflect
functions.description: Returns the reflected angle between two lines.This is the outgoing angle based on the angle of Line 1 and the normalAngle of Line 2.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The base line.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The line to be reflected from the base line.

returns.description: The reflected angle in radians.

members.description: The end point of the line.

members.name: perpSlope

classes.name: Phaser.Matrix
classes.description: The Matrix is a 3x3 matrix mostly used for display transforms within the renderer.It is represented like so:| a | b | tx || c | d | ty || 0 | 0 | 1 |

constructor.name: Matrix
constructor.description: The Matrix is a 3x3 matrix mostly used for display transforms within the renderer.It is represented like so:| a | b | tx || c | d | ty || 0 | 0 | 1 |

functions.name: fromArray
functions.description: Sets the values of this Matrix to the values in the given array.The Array elements should be set as follows:a = array[0]b = array[1]c = array[3]d = array[4]tx = array[2]ty = array[5]

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The array to copy from.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets the values of this Matrix to the given values.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Creates a new Matrix object based on the values of this Matrix.If you provide the output parameter the values of this Matrix will be copied over to it.If the output parameter is blank a new Matrix object will be created.

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: If provided the values of this Matrix will be copied to it, otherwise a new Matrix object is created.

returns.description: A clone of this Matrix.

functions.name: copyTo
functions.description: Copies the properties from this Matrix to the given Matrix.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The Matrix to copy from.

returns.description: The destination Matrix object.

functions.name: copyFrom
functions.description: Copies the properties from the given Matrix into this Matrix.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The Matrix to copy from.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: toArray
functions.description: Creates a Float32 Array with values populated from this Matrix object.

parameters.name: transpose
parameters.description: Whether the values in the array are transposed or not.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: If provided the values will be set into this array, otherwise a new Float32Array is created.

returns.description: The newly created array which contains the matrix.

functions.name: apply
functions.description: Get a new position with the current transformation applied.Can be used to go from a childs coordinate space to the world coordinate space (e.g. rendering)

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The origin Point.

parameters.name: newPos
parameters.description: The point that the new position is assigned to. This can be same as input point.

returns.description: The new point, transformed through this matrix.

functions.name: applyInverse
functions.description: Get a new position with the inverse of the current transformation applied.Can be used to go from the world coordinate space to a childs coordinate space. (e.g. input)

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The origin Point.

parameters.name: newPos
parameters.description: The point that the new position is assigned to. This can be same as input point.

returns.description: The new point, inverse transformed through this matrix.

functions.name: translate
functions.description: Translates the matrix on the x and y.This is the same as Matrix.tx += x.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x value to translate on.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y value to translate on.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: scale
functions.description: Applies a scale transformation to this matrix.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The amount to scale horizontally.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The amount to scale vertically.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: rotate
functions.description: Applies a rotation transformation to this matrix.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle to rotate by, given in radians.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: append
functions.description: Appends the given Matrix to this Matrix.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The matrix to append to this one.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

functions.name: identity
functions.description: Resets this Matrix to an identity (default) matrix.

returns.description: This Matrix object.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

classes.name: Phaser.Point
classes.description: A Point object represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.The following code creates a point at (0,0):`var myPoint = new Phaser.Point();`You can also use them as 2D Vectors and you'll find different vector related methods in this class.

constructor.name: Point
constructor.description: A Point object represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.The following code creates a point at (0,0):`var myPoint = new Phaser.Point();`You can also use them as 2D Vectors and you'll find different vector related methods in this class.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The horizontal position of this Point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The vertical position of this Point.

functions.name: copyFrom
functions.description: Copies the x and y properties from any given object to this Point.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The object to copy from.

returns.description: This Point object.

functions.name: invert
functions.description: Inverts the x and y values of this Point

returns.description: This Point object.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets the `x` and `y` values of this Point object to the given values.If you omit the `y` value then the `x` value will be applied to both, for example:`Point.setTo(2)` is the same as `Point.setTo(2, 2)`

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The horizontal value of this point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The vertical value of this point. If not given the x value will be used in its place.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: set
functions.description: Sets the `x` and `y` values of this Point object to the given values.If you omit the `y` value then the `x` value will be applied to both, for example:`Point.set(2)` is the same as `Point.set(2, 2)`

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The horizontal value of this point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The vertical value of this point. If not given the x value will be used in its place.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: add
functions.description: Adds the given x and y values to this Point.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to add to Point.x.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The value to add to Point.y.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: subtract
functions.description: Subtracts the given x and y values from this Point.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to subtract from Point.x.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The value to subtract from Point.y.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: multiply
functions.description: Multiplies Point.x and Point.y by the given x and y values. Sometimes known as `Scale`.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to multiply Point.x by.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The value to multiply Point.x by.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: divide
functions.description: Divides Point.x and Point.y by the given x and y values.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to divide Point.x by.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The value to divide Point.x by.

returns.description: This Point object. Useful for chaining method calls.

functions.name: clampX
functions.description: Clamps the x value of this Point to be between the given min and max.

parameters.name: min
parameters.description: The minimum value to clamp this Point to.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum value to clamp this Point to.

returns.description: This Point object.

functions.name: clampY
functions.description: Clamps the y value of this Point to be between the given min and max

parameters.name: min
parameters.description: The minimum value to clamp this Point to.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum value to clamp this Point to.

returns.description: This Point object.

functions.name: clamp
functions.description: Clamps this Point object values to be between the given min and max.

parameters.name: min
parameters.description: The minimum value to clamp this Point to.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum value to clamp this Point to.

parameters.description: Optional Point object. If given the values will be set into this object, otherwise a brand new Point object will be created and returned.

functions.name: rotate
functions.description: Rotates a Point object, or any object with exposed x/y properties, around the given coordinates bythe angle specified. If the angle between the point and coordinates was 45 deg and the angle argumentis 45 deg then the resulting angle will be 90 deg, as the angle argument is added to the current angle.The distance allows you to specify a distance constraint for the rotation between the point and the coordinates. If none is given the distance between the two is calculated and used.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The Point object to rotate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the anchor point

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the anchor point

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the Point by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: An optional distance constraint between the Point and the anchor.

returns.description: The modified point object.

parameters.name: yProp
parameters.description: The property used to set the Point.y value.

returns.description: The new Point object.
