classes.name: Phaser.Physics.P2
classes.description: This is your main access to the P2 Physics World.From here you can create materials, listen for events and add bodies into the physics simulation.

constructor.name: P2
constructor.description: This is your main access to the P2 Physics World.From here you can create materials, listen for events and add bodies into the physics simulation.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: Reference to the current game instance.

parameters.name: config
parameters.description: Physics configuration object passed in from the game constructor.

functions.name: removeBodyNextStep
functions.description: This will add a P2 Physics body into the removal list for the next step.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The body to remove at the start of the next step.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Called at the start of the core update loop. Purges flagged bodies from the world.

functions.name: enable
functions.description: This will create a P2 Physics body on the given game object or array of game objects.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.Note: When the game object is enabled for P2 physics it has its anchor x/y set to 0.5 so it becomes centered.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: debug
parameters.description: Create a debug object to go with this body?

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enableBody
functions.description: Creates a P2 Physics body on the given game object.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the body is nulled.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. A body will only be created if this object has a null `body` property.

parameters.name: debug
parameters.description: Create a debug object to go with this body?

functions.name: setImpactEvents
functions.description: Impact event handling is disabled by default. Enable it before any impact events will be dispatched.In a busy world hundreds of impact events can be generated every step, so only enable this if you cannot do what you need via beginContact or collision masks.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Set to true to enable impact events, or false to disable.

functions.name: setPostBroadphaseCallback
functions.description: Sets a callback to be fired after the Broadphase has collected collision pairs in the world.Just because a pair exists it doesn't mean they *will* collide, just that they potentially could do.If your calback returns `false` the pair will be removed from the narrowphase. This will stop them testing for collision this step.Returning `true` from the callback will ensure they are checked in the narrowphase.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will receive the postBroadphase event data. It must return a boolean. Set to null to disable an existing callback.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context under which the callback will be fired.

functions.name: postBroadphaseHandler
functions.description: Internal handler for the postBroadphase event.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event data.

functions.name: impactHandler
functions.description: Handles a p2 impact event.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event data.

functions.name: beginContactHandler
functions.description: Handles a p2 begin contact event.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event data.

functions.name: endContactHandler
functions.description: Handles a p2 end contact event.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event data.

functions.name: updateBoundsCollisionGroup
functions.description: By default the World will be set to collide everything with everything. The bounds of the world is a Body with 4 shapes, one for each face.If you start to use your own collision groups then your objects will no longer collide with the bounds.To fix this you need to adjust the bounds to use its own collision group first BEFORE changing your Sprites collision group.

parameters.name: setCollisionGroup
parameters.description: If true the Bounds will be set to use its own Collision Group.

functions.name: setBounds
functions.description: Sets the bounds of the Physics world to match the given world pixel dimensions.You can optionally set which 'walls' to create: left, right, top or bottom.If none of the walls are given it will default to use the walls settings it had previously.I.e. if you previously told it to not have the left or right walls, and you then adjust the world sizethe newly created bounds will also not have the left and right walls.Explicitly state them in the parameters to override this.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the bounds.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the bounds.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the bounds.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the bounds.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: If true will create the left bounds wall.

parameters.name: right
parameters.description: If true will create the right bounds wall.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: If true will create the top bounds wall.

parameters.name: bottom
parameters.description: If true will create the bottom bounds wall.

parameters.name: setCollisionGroup
parameters.description: If true the Bounds will be set to use its own Collision Group.

functions.name: pause
functions.description: Pauses the P2 World independent of the game pause state.

functions.name: resume
functions.description: Resumes a paused P2 World.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Internal P2 update loop.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Called by Phaser.Physics when a State swap occurs.Starts the begin and end Contact listeners again.

functions.name: clear
functions.description: Clears all bodies from the simulation, resets callbacks and resets the collision bitmask.The P2 world is also cleared:* Removes all solver equations* Removes all constraints* Removes all bodies* Removes all springs* Removes all contact materialsThis is called automatically when you switch state.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Clears all bodies from the simulation and unlinks World from Game. Should only be called on game shutdown. Call `clear` on a State change.

functions.name: addBody
functions.description: Add a body to the world.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The Body to add to the World.

returns.description: True if the Body was added successfully, otherwise false.

functions.name: removeBody
functions.description: Removes a body from the world. This will silently fail if the body wasn't part of the world to begin with.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The Body to remove from the World.

returns.description: The Body that was removed.

functions.name: addSpring
functions.description: Adds a Spring to the world.

parameters.name: spring
parameters.description: The Spring to add to the World.

returns.description: The Spring that was added.

functions.name: removeSpring
functions.description: Removes a Spring from the world.

parameters.name: spring
parameters.description: The Spring to remove from the World.

returns.description: The Spring that was removed.

functions.name: createDistanceConstraint
functions.description: Creates a constraint that tries to keep the distance between two bodies constant.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance to keep between the bodies.

parameters.name: localAnchorA
parameters.description: The anchor point for bodyA, defined locally in bodyA frame. Defaults to [0,0].

parameters.name: localAnchorB
parameters.description: The anchor point for bodyB, defined locally in bodyB frame. Defaults to [0,0].

parameters.name: maxForce
parameters.description: The maximum force that should be applied to constrain the bodies.

returns.description: The constraint

functions.name: createGearConstraint
functions.description: Creates a constraint that tries to keep the distance between two bodies constant.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The relative angle

parameters.name: ratio
parameters.description: The gear ratio.

returns.description: The constraint

functions.name: createRevoluteConstraint
functions.description: Connects two bodies at given offset points, letting them rotate relative to each other around this point.The pivot points are given in world (pixel) coordinates.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: pivotA
parameters.description: The point relative to the center of mass of bodyA which bodyA is constrained to. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: pivotB
parameters.description: The point relative to the center of mass of bodyB which bodyB is constrained to. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: maxForce
parameters.description: The maximum force that should be applied to constrain the bodies.

parameters.name: worldPivot
parameters.description: A pivot point given in world coordinates. If specified, localPivotA and localPivotB are automatically computed from this value.

returns.description: The constraint

functions.name: createLockConstraint
functions.description: Locks the relative position between two bodies.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset of bodyB in bodyA's frame. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of bodyB in bodyA's frame.

parameters.name: maxForce
parameters.description: The maximum force that should be applied to constrain the bodies.

returns.description: The constraint

functions.name: createPrismaticConstraint
functions.description: Constraint that only allows bodies to move along a line, relative to each other.See http://www.iforce2d.net/b2dtut/joints-prismatic

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: lockRotation
parameters.description: If set to false, bodyB will be free to rotate around its anchor point.

parameters.name: anchorA
parameters.description: Body A's anchor point, defined in its own local frame. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: anchorB
parameters.description: Body A's anchor point, defined in its own local frame. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: An axis, defined in body A frame, that body B's anchor point may slide along. The value is an array with 2 elements matching x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: maxForce
parameters.description: The maximum force that should be applied to constrain the bodies.

returns.description: The constraint

functions.name: addConstraint
functions.description: Adds a Constraint to the world.

parameters.name: constraint
parameters.description: The Constraint to add to the World.

returns.description: The Constraint that was added.

functions.name: removeConstraint
functions.description: Removes a Constraint from the world.

parameters.name: constraint
parameters.description: The Constraint to be removed from the World.

returns.description: The Constraint that was removed.

functions.name: addContactMaterial
functions.description: Adds a Contact Material to the world.

parameters.name: material
parameters.description: The Contact Material to be added to the World.

returns.description: The Contact Material that was added.

functions.name: removeContactMaterial
functions.description: Removes a Contact Material from the world.

parameters.name: material
parameters.description: The Contact Material to be removed from the World.

returns.description: The Contact Material that was removed.

functions.name: getContactMaterial
functions.description: Gets a Contact Material based on the two given Materials.

parameters.name: materialA
parameters.description: The first Material to search for.

parameters.name: materialB
parameters.description: The second Material to search for.

returns.description: The Contact Material or false if none was found matching the Materials given.

functions.name: setMaterial
functions.description: Sets the given Material against all Shapes owned by all the Bodies in the given array.

parameters.name: material
parameters.description: The Material to be applied to the given Bodies.

parameters.name: bodies
parameters.description: An Array of Body objects that the given Material will be set on.

functions.name: createMaterial
functions.description: Creates a Material. Materials are applied to Shapes owned by a Body and can be set with Body.setMaterial().Materials are a way to control what happens when Shapes collide. Combine unique Materials together to create Contact Materials.Contact Materials have properties such as friction and restitution that allow for fine-grained collision control between different Materials.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Optional name of the Material. Each Material has a unique ID but string names are handy for debugging.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: Optional Body. If given it will assign the newly created Material to the Body shapes.

returns.description: The Material that was created. This is also stored in Phaser.Physics.P2.materials.

functions.name: createContactMaterial
functions.description: Creates a Contact Material from the two given Materials. You can then edit the properties of the Contact Material directly.

parameters.name: materialA
parameters.description: The first Material to create the ContactMaterial from. If undefined it will create a new Material object first.

parameters.name: materialB
parameters.description: The second Material to create the ContactMaterial from. If undefined it will create a new Material object first.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Material options object.

returns.description: The Contact Material that was created.

functions.name: getBodies
functions.description: Populates and returns an array with references to of all current Bodies in the world.

returns.description: An array containing all current Bodies in the world.

functions.name: getBody
functions.description: Checks the given object to see if it has a p2.Body and if so returns it.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object to check for a p2.Body on.

returns.description: The p2.Body, or null if not found.

functions.name: getSprings
functions.description: Populates and returns an array of all current Springs in the world.

returns.description: An array containing all current Springs in the world.

functions.name: getConstraints
functions.description: Populates and returns an array of all current Constraints in the world.You will get an array of p2 constraints back. This can be of mixed types, for example the array may containPrismaticConstraints, RevoluteConstraints or any other valid p2 constraint type.

returns.description: An array containing all current Constraints in the world.

functions.name: hitTest
functions.description: Test if a world point overlaps bodies. You will get an array of actual P2 bodies back. You can find out which Sprite a Body belongs to(if any) by checking the Body.parent.sprite property. Body.parent is a Phaser.Physics.P2.Body property.

parameters.name: worldPoint
parameters.description: Point to use for intersection tests. The points values must be in world (pixel) coordinates.

parameters.name: bodies
parameters.description: A list of objects to check for intersection. If not given it will check Phaser.Physics.P2.world.bodies (i.e. all world bodies)

parameters.name: precision
parameters.description: Used for matching against particles and lines. Adds some margin to these infinitesimal objects.

parameters.name: filterStatic
parameters.description: If true all Static objects will be removed from the results array.

returns.description: Array of bodies that overlap the point.

functions.name: toJSON
functions.description: Converts the current world into a JSON object.

returns.description: A JSON representation of the world.

functions.name: createCollisionGroup
functions.description: Creates a new Collision Group and optionally applies it to the given object.Collision Groups are handled using bitmasks, therefore you have a fixed limit you can create before you need to re-use older groups.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: An optional Sprite or Group to apply the Collision Group to. If a Group is given it will be applied to all top-level children.

functions.name: createSpring
functions.description: Creates a linear spring, connecting two bodies. A spring can have a resting length, a stiffness and damping.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: restLength
parameters.description: Rest length of the spring. A number > 0.

parameters.name: stiffness
parameters.description: Stiffness of the spring. A number >= 0.

parameters.name: damping
parameters.description: Damping of the spring. A number >= 0.

parameters.name: worldA
parameters.description: Where to hook the spring to body A in world coordinates. This value is an array by 2 elements, x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: worldB
parameters.description: Where to hook the spring to body B in world coordinates. This value is an array by 2 elements, x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: localA
parameters.description: Where to hook the spring to body A in local body coordinates. This value is an array by 2 elements, x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

parameters.name: localB
parameters.description: Where to hook the spring to body B in local body coordinates. This value is an array by 2 elements, x and y, i.e: [32, 32].

returns.description: The spring

functions.name: createRotationalSpring
functions.description: Creates a rotational spring, connecting two bodies. A spring can have a resting length, a stiffness and damping.

parameters.name: bodyA
parameters.description: First connected body.

parameters.name: bodyB
parameters.description: Second connected body.

parameters.name: restAngle
parameters.description: The relative angle of bodies at which the spring is at rest. If not given, it's set to the current relative angle between the bodies.

parameters.name: stiffness
parameters.description: Stiffness of the spring. A number >= 0.

parameters.name: damping
parameters.description: Damping of the spring. A number >= 0.

returns.description: The spring

functions.name: createBody
functions.description: Creates a new Body and adds it to the World.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of Body.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of Body.

parameters.name: mass
parameters.description: The mass of the Body. A mass of 0 means a 'static' Body is created.

parameters.name: addToWorld
parameters.description: Automatically add this Body to the world? (usually false as it won't have any shapes on construction).

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: An object containing the build options:

parameters.name: options.optimalDecomp
parameters.description: Set to true if you need optimal decomposition. Warning: very slow for polygons with more than 10 vertices.

parameters.name: options.skipSimpleCheck
parameters.description: Set to true if you already know that the path is not intersecting itself.

parameters.name: options.removeCollinearPoints
parameters.description: Set to a number (angle threshold value) to remove collinear points, or false to keep all points.

parameters.name: points
parameters.description: An array of 2d vectors that form the convex or concave polygon.                                      Either [[0,0], [0,1],...] or a flat array of numbers that will be interpreted as [x,y, x,y, ...],                                      or the arguments passed can be flat x,y values e.g. `setPolygon(options, x,y, x,y, x,y, ...)` where `x` and `y` are numbers.

returns.description: The body

functions.name: createParticle
functions.description: Creates a new Particle and adds it to the World.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of Body.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of Body.

parameters.name: mass
parameters.description: The mass of the Body. A mass of 0 means a 'static' Body is created.

parameters.name: addToWorld
parameters.description: Automatically add this Body to the world? (usually false as it won't have any shapes on construction).

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: An object containing the build options:

parameters.name: options.optimalDecomp
parameters.description: Set to true if you need optimal decomposition. Warning: very slow for polygons with more than 10 vertices.

parameters.name: options.skipSimpleCheck
parameters.description: Set to true if you already know that the path is not intersecting itself.

parameters.name: options.removeCollinearPoints
parameters.description: Set to a number (angle threshold value) to remove collinear points, or false to keep all points.

parameters.name: points
parameters.description: An array of 2d vectors that form the convex or concave polygon.                                      Either [[0,0], [0,1],...] or a flat array of numbers that will be interpreted as [x,y, x,y, ...],                                      or the arguments passed can be flat x,y values e.g. `setPolygon(options, x,y, x,y, x,y, ...)` where `x` and `y` are numbers.

functions.name: convertCollisionObjects
functions.description: Converts all of the polylines objects inside a Tiled ObjectGroup into physics bodies that are added to the world.Note that the polylines must be created in such a way that they can withstand polygon decomposition.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The Tilemap to get the map data from.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to map.currentLayer.

parameters.name: addToWorld
parameters.description: If true it will automatically add each body to the world.

returns.description: An array of the Phaser.Physics.Body objects that have been created.

functions.name: clearTilemapLayerBodies
functions.description: Clears all physics bodies from the given TilemapLayer that were created with `World.convertTilemap`.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The Tilemap to get the map data from.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to map.currentLayer.

functions.name: convertTilemap
functions.description: Goes through all tiles in the given Tilemap and TilemapLayer and converts those set to collide into physics bodies.Only call this *after* you have specified all of the tiles you wish to collide with calls like Tilemap.setCollisionBetween, etc.Every time you call this method it will destroy any previously created bodies and remove them from the world.Therefore understand it's a very expensive operation and not to be done in a core game update loop.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The Tilemap to get the map data from.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to map.currentLayer.

parameters.name: addToWorld
parameters.description: If true it will automatically add each body to the world, otherwise it's up to you to do so.

parameters.name: optimize
parameters.description: If true adjacent colliding tiles will be combined into a single body to save processing. However it means you cannot perform specific Tile to Body collision responses.

returns.description: An array of the Phaser.Physics.P2.Body objects that were created.

functions.name: mpx
functions.description: Convert p2 physics value (meters) to pixel scale.By default Phaser uses a scale of 20px per meter.If you need to modify this you can over-ride these functions via the Physics Configuration object.

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: The value to convert.

returns.description: The scaled value.

functions.name: pxm
functions.description: Convert pixel value to p2 physics scale (meters).By default Phaser uses a scale of 20px per meter.If you need to modify this you can over-ride these functions via the Physics Configuration object.

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: The value to convert.

returns.description: The scaled value.

functions.name: mpxi
functions.description: Convert p2 physics value (meters) to pixel scale and inverses it.By default Phaser uses a scale of 20px per meter.If you need to modify this you can over-ride these functions via the Physics Configuration object.

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: The value to convert.

returns.description: The scaled value.

functions.name: pxmi
functions.description: Convert pixel value to p2 physics scale (meters) and inverses it.By default Phaser uses a scale of 20px per meter.If you need to modify this you can over-ride these functions via the Physics Configuration object.

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: The value to convert.

returns.description: The scaled value.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: config
members.description: The p2 World configuration object.

members.name: world
members.description: The p2 World in which the simulation is run.

members.name: frameRate
members.description: The frame rate the world will be stepped at. Defaults to 1 / 60, but you can change here. Also see useElapsedTime property.

members.name: useElapsedTime
members.description: If true the frameRate value will be ignored and instead p2 will step with the value of Game.Time.physicsElapsed, which is a delta time value.

members.name: paused
members.description: The paused state of the P2 World.

members.name: materials
members.description: A local array of all created Materials.

members.name: gravity
members.description: The gravity applied to all bodies each step.

members.name: walls
members.description: An object containing the 4 wall bodies that bound the physics world.

members.name: onBodyAdded
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a new Body is added to the World.It sends 1 argument: `body` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.Body` that was added to the world.

members.name: onBodyRemoved
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Body is removed to the World.It sends 1 argument: `body` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.Body` that was removed from the world.

members.name: onSpringAdded
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Spring is added to the World.It sends 1 argument: `spring` which is either a `Phaser.Physics.P2.Spring`, `p2.LinearSpring` or `p2.RotationalSpring` that was added to the world.

members.name: onSpringRemoved
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Spring is removed from the World.It sends 1 argument: `spring` which is either a `Phaser.Physics.P2.Spring`, `p2.LinearSpring` or `p2.RotationalSpring` that was removed from the world.

members.name: onConstraintAdded
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Constraint is added to the World.It sends 1 argument: `constraint` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.Constraint` that was added to the world.

members.name: onConstraintRemoved
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Constraint is removed from the World.It sends 1 argument: `constraint` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.Constraint` that was removed from the world.

members.name: onContactMaterialAdded
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Contact Material is added to the World.It sends 1 argument: `material` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.ContactMaterial` that was added to the world.

members.name: onContactMaterialRemoved
members.description: This signal is dispatched when a Contact Material is removed from the World.It sends 1 argument: `material` which is the `Phaser.Physics.P2.ContactMaterial` that was removed from the world.

members.name: postBroadphaseCallback
members.description: A postBroadphase callback.

members.name: callbackContext
members.description: The context under which the callbacks are fired.

members.name: onBeginContact
members.description: This Signal is dispatched when a first contact is created between two bodies. This happens *before* the step has been done.It sends 5 arguments: `bodyA`, `bodyB`, `shapeA`, `shapeB` and `contactEquations`.It is possible that in certain situations the `bodyA` or `bodyB` values are `null`. You should check for thisin your own code to avoid processing potentially null physics bodies.

members.name: onEndContact
members.description: This Signal is dispatched when final contact occurs between two bodies. This happens *before* the step has been done.It sends 4 arguments: `bodyA`, `bodyB`, `shapeA` and `shapeB`.It is possible that in certain situations the `bodyA` or `bodyB` values are `null`. You should check for thisin your own code to avoid processing potentially null physics bodies.

members.name: collisionGroups
members.description: An array containing the collision groups that have been defined in the World.

members.name: nothingCollisionGroup
members.description: A default collision group.

members.name: boundsCollisionGroup
members.description: A default collision group.

members.name: everythingCollisionGroup
members.description: A default collision group.

members.name: boundsCollidesWith
members.description: An array of the bodies the world bounds collides with.

members.name: _toRemove
members.description: Internal var used to hold references to bodies to remove from the world on the next step.

members.name: _collisionGroupID
members.description: Internal var.

members.name: _boundsLeft
members.description: Internal var that keeps track of world bounds settings.

members.name: _boundsRight
members.description: Internal var that keeps track of world bounds settings.

members.name: _boundsTop
members.description: Internal var that keeps track of world bounds settings.

members.name: _boundsBottom
members.description: Internal var that keeps track of world bounds settings.

members.name: _boundsOwnGroup
members.description: Internal var that keeps track of world bounds settings.

members.name: friction
members.description: Friction between colliding bodies. This value is used if no matching ContactMaterial is found for a Material pair.

members.name: restitution
members.description: Default coefficient of restitution between colliding bodies. This value is used if no matching ContactMaterial is found for a Material pair.

members.name: contactMaterial
members.description: The default Contact Material being used by the World.

members.name: applySpringForces
members.description: Enable to automatically apply spring forces each step.

members.name: applyDamping
members.description: Enable to automatically apply body damping each step.

members.name: applyGravity
members.description: Enable to automatically apply gravity each step.

members.name: solveConstraints
members.description: Enable/disable constraint solving in each step.

members.name: time
members.description: The World time.

members.name: emitImpactEvent
members.description: Set to true if you want to the world to emit the "impact" event. Turning this off could improve performance.

members.name: sleepMode
members.description: How to deactivate bodies during simulation. Possible modes are: World.NO_SLEEPING, World.BODY_SLEEPING and World.ISLAND_SLEEPING.If sleeping is enabled, you might need to wake up the bodies if they fall asleep when they shouldn't. If you want to enable sleeping in the world, but want to disable it for a particular body, see Body.allowSleep.

members.name: total
members.description: The total number of bodies in the world.

classes.name: Phaser.Physics
classes.description: The Physics Manager is responsible for looking after all of the running physics systems.Phaser supports 4 physics systems: Arcade Physics, P2, Ninja Physics and Box2D via a commercial plugin.Game Objects (such as Sprites) can only belong to 1 physics system, but you can have multiple systems active in a single game.For example you could have P2 managing a polygon-built terrain landscape that an vehicle drives over, while it could be firing bullets that use thefaster (due to being much simpler) Arcade Physics system.

constructor.name: Physics
constructor.description: The Physics Manager is responsible for looking after all of the running physics systems.Phaser supports 4 physics systems: Arcade Physics, P2, Ninja Physics and Box2D via a commercial plugin.Game Objects (such as Sprites) can only belong to 1 physics system, but you can have multiple systems active in a single game.For example you could have P2 managing a polygon-built terrain landscape that an vehicle drives over, while it could be firing bullets that use thefaster (due to being much simpler) Arcade Physics system.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: physicsConfig
parameters.description: A physics configuration object to pass to the Physics world on creation.

functions.name: parseConfig
functions.description: Parses the Physics Configuration object passed to the Game constructor and starts any physics systems specified within.

functions.name: startSystem
functions.description: This will create an instance of the requested physics simulation.Phaser.Physics.Arcade is running by default, but all others need activating directly.You can start the following physics systems:Phaser.Physics.P2JS - A full-body advanced physics system by Stefan Hedman.Phaser.Physics.NINJA - A port of Metanet Softwares N+ physics system.Phaser.Physics.BOX2D - A commercial Phaser Plugin (see http://phaser.io)Both Ninja Physics and Box2D require their respective plugins to be loaded before you can start them.They are not bundled into the core Phaser library.If the physics world has already been created (i.e. in another state in your game) then calling startSystem will reset the physics world, not re-create it. If you need to start them again from their constructors then set Phaser.Physics.p2 (or whichever system you want to recreate) to `null` before calling `startSystem`.

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: The physics system to start: Phaser.Physics.ARCADE, Phaser.Physics.P2JS, Phaser.Physics.NINJA or Phaser.Physics.BOX2D.

functions.name: enable
functions.description: This will create a default physics body on the given game object or array of objects.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.It can be for any of the physics systems that have been started:Phaser.Physics.Arcade - A light weight AABB based collision system with basic separation.Phaser.Physics.P2JS - A full-body advanced physics system supporting multiple object shapes, polygon loading, contact materials, springs and constraints.Phaser.Physics.NINJA - A port of Metanet Softwares N+ physics system. Advanced AABB and Circle vs. Tile collision.Phaser.Physics.BOX2D - A port of https://code.google.com/p/box2d-html5Phaser.Physics.MATTER - A full-body and light-weight advanced physics system (still in development)Phaser.Physics.CHIPMUNK is still in development.If you require more control over what type of body is created, for example to create a Ninja Physics Circle instead of the default AABB, then see theindividual physics systems `enable` methods instead of using this generic one.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array of objects, a body will be created on every object in the array.

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: The physics system that will be used to create the body. Defaults to Arcade Physics.

parameters.name: debug

functions.description: Adds a marker into the current Sound. A marker is represented by a unique key and a start time and duration.This allows you to bundle multiple sounds together into a single audio file and use markers to jump between them for playback.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A unique name for this marker, i.e. 'explosion', 'gunshot', etc.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: The start point of this marker in the audio file, given in seconds. 2.5 = 2500ms, 0.5 = 500ms, etc.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the marker in seconds. 2.5 = 2500ms, 0.5 = 500ms, etc.

functions.description: Called automatically by the AudioContext when the sound stops playing.Doesn't get called if the sound is set to loop or is a section of an Audio Sprite.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Called automatically by Phaser.SoundManager.

functions.name: loopFull
functions.description: Loops this entire sound. If you need to loop a section of it then use Sound.play and the marker and loop parameters.

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: Volume of the sound you want to play. If none is given it will use the volume given to the Sound when it was created (which defaults to 1 if none was specified).

returns.description: This sound instance.

functions.name: play
functions.description: Play this sound, or a marked section of it.

parameters.name: marker
parameters.description: If you want to play a marker then give the key here, otherwise leave blank to play the full sound.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The starting position to play the sound from - this is ignored if you provide a marker.

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: Volume of the sound you want to play. If none is given it will use the volume given to the Sound when it was created (which defaults to 1 if none was specified).

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Loop when finished playing? If not using a marker / audio sprite the looping will be done via the WebAudio loop property, otherwise it's time based.

parameters.name: forceRestart
parameters.description: If the sound is already playing you can set forceRestart to restart it from the beginning.

returns.description: This sound instance.

functions.name: restart
functions.description: Restart the sound, or a marked section of it.

parameters.name: marker
parameters.description: If you want to play a marker then give the key here, otherwise leave blank to play the full sound.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The starting position to play the sound from - this is ignored if you provide a marker.

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: Volume of the sound you want to play.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Loop when it finished playing?

functions.name: pause
functions.description: Pauses the sound.

functions.name: resume
functions.description: Resumes the sound.

functions.name: stop
functions.description: Stop playing this sound.

functions.name: fadeIn
functions.description: Starts this sound playing (or restarts it if already doing so) and sets the volume to zero.Then increases the volume from 0 to 1 over the duration specified.At the end of the fade Sound.onFadeComplete is dispatched with this Sound object as the first parameter,and the final volume (1) as the second parameter.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The time in milliseconds over which the Sound should fade in.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the Sound be set to loop? Note that this doesn't cause the fade to repeat.

parameters.name: marker
parameters.description: The marker to start at; defaults to the current (last played) marker. To start playing from the beginning specify specify a marker of `''`.

functions.name: fadeOut
functions.description: Decreases the volume of this Sound from its current value to 0 over the duration specified.At the end of the fade Sound.onFadeComplete is dispatched with this Sound object as the first parameter,and the final volume (0) as the second parameter.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The time in milliseconds over which the Sound should fade out.

functions.name: fadeTo
functions.description: Fades the volume of this Sound from its current value to the given volume over the duration specified.At the end of the fade Sound.onFadeComplete is dispatched with this Sound object as the first parameter, and the final volume (volume) as the second parameter.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The time in milliseconds during which the Sound should fade out.

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: The volume which the Sound should fade to. This is a value between 0 and 1.

functions.name: fadeComplete
functions.description: Internal handler for Sound.fadeIn, Sound.fadeOut and Sound.fadeTo.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this sound and all associated events and removes it from the SoundManager.

parameters.name: remove
parameters.description: If true this Sound is automatically removed from the SoundManager.

classes.name: Phaser.SoundManager
classes.description: The Sound Manager is responsible for playing back audio via either the Legacy HTML Audio tag or via Web Audio if the browser supports it.Note: On Firefox 25+ on Linux if you have media.gstreamer disabled in about:config then it cannot play back mp3 or m4a files.The audio file type and the encoding of those files are extremely important. Not all browsers can play all audio formats.There is a good guide to what's supported here: http://hpr.dogphilosophy.net/test/If you are reloading a Phaser Game on a page that never properly refreshes (such as in an AngularJS project) then you will quickly run outof AudioContext nodes. If this is the case create a global var called PhaserGlobal on the window object before creating the game. The activeAudioContext will then be saved to window.PhaserGlobal.audioContext when the Phaser game is destroyed, and re-used when it starts again.Mobile warning: There are some mobile devices (certain iPad 2 and iPad Mini revisions) that cannot play 48000 Hz audio.When they try to play the audio becomes extremely distorted and buzzes, eventually crashing the sound system.The solution is to use a lower encoding rate such as 44100 Hz.

constructor.name: SoundManager
constructor.description: The Sound Manager is responsible for playing back audio via either the Legacy HTML Audio tag or via Web Audio if the browser supports it.Note: On Firefox 25+ on Linux if you have media.gstreamer disabled in about:config then it cannot play back mp3 or m4a files.The audio file type and the encoding of those files are extremely important. Not all browsers can play all audio formats.There is a good guide to what's supported here: http://hpr.dogphilosophy.net/test/If you are reloading a Phaser Game on a page that never properly refreshes (such as in an AngularJS project) then you will quickly run outof AudioContext nodes. If this is the case create a global var called PhaserGlobal on the window object before creating the game. The activeAudioContext will then be saved to window.PhaserGlobal.audioContext when the Phaser game is destroyed, and re-used when it starts again.Mobile warning: There are some mobile devices (certain iPad 2 and iPad Mini revisions) that cannot play 48000 Hz audio.When they try to play the audio becomes extremely distorted and buzzes, eventually crashing the sound system.The solution is to use a lower encoding rate such as 44100 Hz.

functions.name: setDecodedCallback
functions.description: This method allows you to give the SoundManager a list of Sound files, or keys, and a callback.Once all of the Sound files have finished decoding the callback will be invoked.The amount of time spent decoding depends on the codec used and file size.If all of the files given have already decoded the callback is triggered immediately.

parameters.name: files
parameters.description: An array containing either Phaser.Sound objects or their key strings as found in the Phaser.Cache.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback which will be invoked once all files have finished decoding.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will run.

classes.name: Phaser.Canvas
classes.description: The Canvas class handles everything related to creating the `canvas` DOM tag that Phaser will use, including styles, offset and aspect ratio.

constructor.name: Canvas
constructor.description: The Canvas class handles everything related to creating the `canvas` DOM tag that Phaser will use, including styles, offset and aspect ratio.

functions.name: create
functions.description: Creates a `canvas` DOM element. The element is not automatically added to the document.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The object that will own the canvas that is created.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the canvas element.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the canvas element..

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: If specified, and not the empty string, this will be set as the ID of the canvas element. Otherwise no ID will be set.

parameters.name: skipPool
parameters.description: If `true` the canvas will not be placed in the CanvasPool global.

returns.description: The newly created canvas element.

functions.name: setBackgroundColor
functions.description: Sets the background color behind the canvas. This changes the canvas style property.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to set the background color on.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: The color to set. Can be in the format 'rgb(r,g,b)', or '#RRGGBB' or any valid CSS color.

returns.description: Returns the source canvas.

functions.name: setTouchAction
functions.description: Sets the touch-action property on the canvas style. Can be used to disable default browser touch actions.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to set the touch action on.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The touch action to set. Defaults to 'none'.

returns.description: The source canvas.

functions.name: setUserSelect
functions.description: Sets the user-select property on the canvas style. Can be used to disable default browser selection actions.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to set the touch action on.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The touch action to set. Defaults to 'none'.

returns.description: The source canvas.

functions.name: addToDOM
functions.description: Adds the given canvas element to the DOM. The canvas will be added as a child of the given parent.If no parent is given it will be added as a child of the document.body.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to be added to the DOM.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The DOM element to add the canvas to.

parameters.name: overflowHidden
parameters.description: If set to true it will add the overflow='hidden' style to the parent DOM element.

returns.description: Returns the source canvas.

functions.name: removeFromDOM
functions.description: Removes the given canvas element from the DOM.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to be removed from the DOM.

functions.name: setTransform
functions.description: Sets the transform of the given canvas to the matrix values provided.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context to set the transform on.

parameters.name: translateX
parameters.description: The value to translate horizontally by.

parameters.name: translateY
parameters.description: The value to translate vertically by.

parameters.name: scaleX
parameters.description: The value to scale horizontally by.

parameters.name: scaleY
parameters.description: The value to scale vertically by.

parameters.name: skewX
parameters.description: The value to skew horizontaly by.

parameters.name: skewY
parameters.description: The value to skew vertically by.

returns.description: Returns the source context.

functions.name: setSmoothingEnabled
functions.description: Sets the Image Smoothing property on the given context. Set to false to disable image smoothing.By default browsers have image smoothing enabled, which isn't always what you visually want, especiallywhen using pixel art in a game. Note that this sets the property on the context itself, so that any imagedrawn to the context will be affected. This sets the property across all current browsers but support ispatchy on earlier browsers, especially on mobile.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context to enable or disable the image smoothing on.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: If set to true it will enable image smoothing, false will disable it.

returns.description: Returns the source context.

functions.name: getSmoothingEnabled
functions.description: Returns `true` if the given context has image smoothing enabled, otherwise returns `false`.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context to check for smoothing on.

returns.description: True if the given context has image smoothing enabled, otherwise false.

functions.name: setImageRenderingCrisp
functions.description: Sets the CSS image-rendering property on the given canvas to be 'crisp' (aka 'optimize contrast' on webkit).Note that if this doesn't given the desired result then see the setSmoothingEnabled.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to set image-rendering crisp on.

returns.description: Returns the source canvas.

functions.name: setImageRenderingBicubic
functions.description: Sets the CSS image-rendering property on the given canvas to be 'bicubic' (aka 'auto').Note that if this doesn't given the desired result then see the CanvasUtils.setSmoothingEnabled method.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.description: The canvas to set image-rendering bicubic on.

returns.description: Returns the source canvas.

classes.name: Phaser.Device
classes.description: Detects device support capabilities and is responsible for device intialization - see {@link Phaser.Device.whenReady whenReady}.This class represents a singleton object that can be accessed directly as `game.device`(or, as a fallback, `Phaser.Device` when a game instance is not available) without the need to instantiate it.Unless otherwise noted the device capabilities are only guaranteed after initialization. Initializationoccurs automatically and is guaranteed complete before {@link Phaser.Game} begins its "boot" phase.Feature detection can be modified in the {@link Phaser.Device.onInitialized onInitialized} signal.When checking features using the exposed properties only the *truth-iness* of the value should be relied uponunless the documentation states otherwise: properties may return `false`, `''`, `null`, or even `undefined`when indicating the lack of a feature.Uses elements from System.js by MrDoob and Modernizr

constructor.name: Device
constructor.description: It is not possible to instantiate the Device class manually.

functions.name: whenReady
functions.description: Add a device-ready handler and ensure the device ready sequence is started.Phaser.Device will _not_ activate or initialize until at least one `whenReady` handler is added,which is normally done automatically be calling `new Phaser.Game(..)`.The handler is invoked when the device is considered "ready", which may be immediatelyif the device is already "ready". See {@link Phaser.Device#deviceReadyAt deviceReadyAt}.

parameters.name: handler
parameters.description: Callback to invoke when the device is ready. It is invoked with the given context the Phaser.Device object is supplied as the first argument.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: Context in which to invoke the handler

parameters.name: nonPrimer
parameters.description: If true the device ready check will not be started.

functions.name: _readyCheck
functions.description: Internal method used for checking when the device is ready.This function is removed from Phaser.Device when the device becomes ready.

functions.name: _initialize
functions.description: Internal method to initialize the capability checks.This function is removed from Phaser.Device once the device is initialized.

functions.name: canPlayAudio
functions.description: Check whether the host environment can play audio.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: One of 'mp3, 'ogg', 'm4a', 'wav', 'webm' or 'opus'.

returns.description: True if the given file type is supported by the browser, otherwise false.

functions.name: canPlayVideo
functions.description: Check whether the host environment can play video files.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: One of 'mp4, 'ogg', 'webm' or 'mpeg'.

classes.name: Phaser.DOM
classes.description: DOM utility class.Provides a useful Window and Element functions as well as cross-browser compatibility buffer.Some code originally derived from {@link https://github.com/ryanve/verge verge}.Some parts were inspired by the research of Ryan Van Etten, released under MIT License 2013.

constructor.name: DOM
constructor.description: DOM utility class.Provides a useful Window and Element functions as well as cross-browser compatibility buffer.Some code originally derived from {@link https://github.com/ryanve/verge verge}.Some parts were inspired by the research of Ryan Van Etten, released under MIT License 2013.

functions.name: getOffset
functions.description: Get the [absolute] position of the element relative to the Document.The value may vary slightly as the page is scrolled due to rounding errors.

parameters.name: element
parameters.description: The targeted element that we want to retrieve the offset.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The point we want to take the x/y values of the offset.

returns.description: - A point objet with the offsetX and Y as its properties.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: A cross-browser element.getBoundingClientRect method with optional cushion.Returns a plain object containing the properties `top/bottom/left/right/width/height` with respect to the top-left corner of the current viewport.Its properties match the native rectangle.The cushion parameter is an amount of pixels (+/-) to cushion the element.It adjusts the measurements such that it is possible to detect when an element is near the viewport.

parameters.name: element
parameters.description: The element or stack (uses first item) to get the bounds for.

parameters.name: cushion
parameters.description: A +/- pixel adjustment amount.

returns.description: A plain object containing the properties `top/bottom/left/right/width/height` or `false` if a non-valid element is given.

functions.name: calibrate
functions.description: Calibrates element coordinates for `inLayoutViewport` checks.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description: An object containing the following properties: `{top: number, right: number, bottom: number, left: number}`

parameters.name: cushion
parameters.description: A value to adjust the coordinates by.

returns.description: The calibrated element coordinates

functions.name: getAspectRatio
functions.description: Get the Visual viewport aspect ratio (or the aspect ratio of an object or element)

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object to determine the aspect ratio for. Must have public `width` and `height` properties or methods.

returns.description: The aspect ratio.

functions.name: inLayoutViewport
functions.description: Tests if the given DOM element is within the Layout viewport.The optional cushion parameter allows you to specify a distance.inLayoutViewport(element, 100) is `true` if the element is in the viewport or 100px near it.inLayoutViewport(element, -100) is `true` if the element is in the viewport or at least 100px near it.

parameters.name: element
parameters.description: The DOM element to check. If no element is given it defaults to the Phaser game canvas.

parameters.name: cushion
parameters.description: The cushion allows you to specify a distance within which the element must be within the viewport.

returns.description: True if the element is within the viewport, or within `cushion` distance from it.

functions.name: getScreenOrientation
functions.description: Returns the device screen orientation.Orientation values: 'portrait-primary', 'landscape-primary', 'portrait-secondary', 'landscape-secondary'.Order of resolving:- Screen Orientation API, or variation of - Future track. Most desktop and mobile browsers.- Screen size ratio check - If fallback is 'screen', suited for desktops.- Viewport size ratio check - If fallback is 'viewport', suited for mobile.- window.orientation - If fallback is 'window.orientation', works iOS and probably most Android; non-recommended track.- Media query- Viewport size ratio check (probably only IE9 and legacy mobile gets here..)See- https://w3c.github.io/screen-orientation/ (conflicts with mozOrientation/msOrientation)- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Screen.orientation (mozOrientation)- http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn342934(v=vs.85).aspx- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/CSS/Testing_media_queries- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4917664/detect-viewport-orientation- http://www.matthewgifford.com/blog/2011/12/22/a-misconception-about-window-orientation

parameters.name: primaryFallback
parameters.description: Specify 'screen', 'viewport', or 'window.orientation'.

members.name: visualBounds
members.description: The bounds of the Visual viewport, as discussed in {@link http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/viewports.html A tale of two viewports  part one}with one difference: the viewport size _excludes_ scrollbars, as found on some desktop browsers.   Supported mobile:  iOS/Safari, Android 4, IE10, Firefox OS (maybe not Firefox Android), Opera Mobile 16The properties change dynamically.

members.name: layoutBounds
members.description: The bounds of the Layout viewport, as discussed in {@link http://www.quirksmode.org/mobile/viewports2.html A tale of two viewports  part two};but honoring the constraints as specified applicable viewport meta-tag.The bounds returned are not guaranteed to be fully aligned with CSS media queries (see{@link http://www.matanich.com/2013/01/07/viewport-size/ What size is my viewport?}).This is _not_ representative of the Visual bounds: in particular the non-primary axis willgenerally be significantly larger than the screen height on mobile devices when running with aconstrained viewport.The properties change dynamically.

members.name: documentBounds
members.description: The size of the document / Layout viewport.This incorrectly reports the dimensions in IE.The properties change dynamically.

members.description: A cross-browser window.scrollX.

members.name: scrollY
members.description: A cross-browser window.scrollY.

classes.name: Phaser.Tilemap
classes.description: Creates a new Phaser.Tilemap object. The map can either be populated with data from a Tiled JSON file or from a CSV file.To do this pass the Cache key as the first parameter. When using Tiled data you need only provide the key.When using CSV data you must provide the key and the tileWidth and tileHeight parameters.If creating a blank tilemap to be populated later, you can either specify no parameters at all and then use `Tilemap.create` or pass the map and tile dimensions here.Note that all Tilemaps use a base tile size to calculate dimensions from, but that a TilemapLayer may have its own unique tile size that overrides it.A Tile map is rendered to the display using a TilemapLayer. It is not added to the display list directly itself.A map may have multiple layers. You can perform operations on the map data such as copying, pasting, filling and shuffling the tiles around.

constructor.name: Tilemap
constructor.description: Creates a new Phaser.Tilemap object. The map can either be populated with data from a Tiled JSON file or from a CSV file.To do this pass the Cache key as the first parameter. When using Tiled data you need only provide the key.When using CSV data you must provide the key and the tileWidth and tileHeight parameters.If creating a blank tilemap to be populated later, you can either specify no parameters at all and then use `Tilemap.create` or pass the map and tile dimensions here.Note that all Tilemaps use a base tile size to calculate dimensions from, but that a TilemapLayer may have its own unique tile size that overrides it.A Tile map is rendered to the display using a TilemapLayer. It is not added to the display list directly itself.A map may have multiple layers. You can perform operations on the map data such as copying, pasting, filling and shuffling the tiles around.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: Game reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the tilemap data as stored in the Cache. If you're creating a blank map either leave this parameter out or pass `null`.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The pixel width of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The pixel height of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

functions.name: create
functions.description: Creates an empty map of the given dimensions and one blank layer. If layers already exist they are erased.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the default layer of the map.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the map in tiles.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the map in tiles.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The width of the tiles the map uses for calculations.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The height of the tiles the map uses for calculations.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the layer to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The TilemapLayer object. This is an extension of Phaser.Image and can be moved around the display list accordingly.

functions.name: setTileSize
functions.description: Sets the base tile size for the map.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The width of the tiles the map uses for calculations.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The height of the tiles the map uses for calculations.

functions.name: addTilesetImage
functions.description: Adds an image to the map to be used as a tileset. A single map may use multiple tilesets.Note that the tileset name can be found in the JSON file exported from Tiled, or in the Tiled editor.

parameters.name: tileset
parameters.description: The name of the tileset as specified in the map data.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the Phaser.Cache image used for this tileset.    If `undefined` or `null` it will look for an image with a key matching the tileset parameter.    You can also pass in a BitmapData which can be used instead of an Image.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The width of the tiles in the Tileset Image. If not given it will default to the map.tileWidth value, if that isn't set then 32.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The height of the tiles in the Tileset Image. If not given it will default to the map.tileHeight value, if that isn't set then 32.

parameters.name: tileMargin
parameters.description: The width of the tiles in the Tileset Image. If not given it will default to the map.tileWidth value.

parameters.name: tileSpacing
parameters.description: The height of the tiles in the Tileset Image. If not given it will default to the map.tileHeight value.

parameters.name: gid
parameters.description: If adding multiple tilesets to a blank/dynamic map, specify the starting GID the set will use here.

returns.description: Returns the Tileset object that was created or updated, or null if it failed.

functions.name: createFromObjects
functions.description: Creates a Sprite for every object matching the given gid in the map data. You can optionally specify the group that the Sprite will be created in. If none isgiven it will be created in the World. All properties from the map data objectgroup are copied across to the Sprite, so you can use this as an easy way toconfigure Sprite properties from within the map editor. For example giving an object a property of alpha: 0.5 in the map editor will duplicate that when theSprite is created. You could also give it a value like: body.velocity.x: 100 to set it moving automatically.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the Object Group to create Sprites from.

parameters.name: gid
parameters.description: The layer array index value, or if a string is given the layer name within the map data.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The Game.cache key of the image that this Sprite will use.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If the Sprite image contains multiple frames you can specify which one to use here.

parameters.name: exists
parameters.description: The default exists state of the Sprite.

parameters.name: autoCull
parameters.description: The default autoCull state of the Sprite. Sprites that are autoCulled are culled from the camera if out of its range.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Group to add the Sprite to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

parameters.name: CustomClass
parameters.description: If you wish to create your own class, rather than Phaser.Sprite, pass the class here. Your class must extend Phaser.Sprite and have the same constructor parameters.

parameters.name: adjustY
parameters.description: By default the Tiled map editor uses a bottom-left coordinate system. Phaser uses top-left. So most objects will appear too low down. This parameter moves them up by their height.

functions.name: createFromTiles
functions.description: Creates a Sprite for every object matching the given tile indexes in the map data.You can specify the group that the Sprite will be created in. If none is given it will be created in the World.You can optional specify if the tile will be replaced with another after the Sprite is created. This is useful if you want to lay down special tiles in a level that are converted to Sprites, but want to replace the tile itself with a floor tile or similar once converted.

parameters.name: tiles
parameters.description: The tile index, or array of indexes, to create Sprites from.

parameters.name: replacements
parameters.description: The tile index, or array of indexes, to change a converted tile to. Set to `null` to not change.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The Game.cache key of the image that this Sprite will use.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Group to add the Sprite to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

parameters.name: properties
parameters.description: An object that contains the default properties for your newly created Sprite. This object will be iterated and any matching Sprite property will be set.

returns.description: The number of Sprites that were created.

functions.name: createLayer
functions.description: Creates a new TilemapLayer object. By default TilemapLayers are fixed to the camera.The `layer` parameter is important. If you've created your map in Tiled then you can get this by looking in Tiled and looking at the Layer name.Or you can open the JSON file it exports and look at the layers[].name value. Either way it must match.If you wish to create a blank layer to put your own tiles on then see Tilemap.createBlankLayer.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer array index value, or if a string is given the layer name, within the map data that this TilemapLayer represents.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The rendered width of the layer, should never be wider than Game.width. If not given it will be set to Game.width.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The rendered height of the layer, should never be wider than Game.height. If not given it will be set to Game.height.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The TilemapLayer object. This is an extension of Phaser.Sprite and can be moved around the display list accordingly.

functions.name: createBlankLayer
functions.description: Creates a new and empty layer on this Tilemap. By default TilemapLayers are fixed to the camera.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of this layer. Must be unique within the map.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the layer in tiles.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the layer in tiles.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The width of the tiles the layer uses for calculations.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The height of the tiles the layer uses for calculations.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: Optional Group to add the layer to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.

returns.description: The TilemapLayer object. This is an extension of Phaser.Image and can be moved around the display list accordingly.

functions.name: getIndex
functions.description: Gets the layer index based on the layers name.

parameters.name: location
parameters.description: The local array to search.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the array element to get.

returns.description: The index of the element in the array, or null if not found.

functions.name: getLayerIndex
functions.description: Gets the layer index based on its name.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the layer to get.

returns.description: The index of the layer in this tilemap, or null if not found.

functions.name: getTilesetIndex
functions.description: Gets the tileset index based on its name.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the tileset to get.

returns.description: The index of the tileset in this tilemap, or null if not found.

functions.name: getImageIndex
functions.description: Gets the image index based on its name.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the image to get.

returns.description: The index of the image in this tilemap, or null if not found.

functions.name: getObjectIndex
functions.description: Gets the object index based on its name.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the object to get.

returns.description: The index of the object in this tilemap, or null if not found.

functions.name: setTileIndexCallback
functions.description: Sets a global collision callback for the given tile index within the layer. This will affect all tiles on this layer that have the same index.If a callback is already set for the tile index it will be replaced. Set the callback to null to remove it.If you want to set a callback for a tile at a specific location on the map then see setTileLocationCallback.

parameters.name: indexes
parameters.description: Either a single tile index, or an array of tile indexes to have a collision callback set for.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be invoked when the tile is collided with.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context under which the callback is called.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

functions.name: setTileLocationCallback
functions.description: Sets a global collision callback for the given map location within the layer. This will affect all tiles on this layer found in the given area.If a callback is already set for the tile index it will be replaced. Set the callback to null to remove it.If you want to set a callback for a tile at a specific location on the map then see setTileLocationCallback.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the top left of the area to copy (given in tiles, not pixels)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the top left of the area to copy (given in tiles, not pixels)

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the area to copy (given in tiles, not pixels)

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the area to copy (given in tiles, not pixels)

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be invoked when the tile is collided with.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context under which the callback is called.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

functions.name: setCollision
functions.description: Sets collision the given tile or tiles. You can pass in either a single numeric index or an array of indexes: [ 2, 3, 15, 20].The `collides` parameter controls if collision will be enabled (true) or disabled (false).

parameters.name: indexes
parameters.description: Either a single tile index, or an array of tile IDs to be checked for collision.

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true it will enable collision. If false it will clear collision.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

parameters.name: recalculate
parameters.description: Recalculates the tile faces after the update.

functions.name: setCollisionBetween
functions.description: Sets collision on a range of tiles where the tile IDs increment sequentially.Calling this with a start value of 10 and a stop value of 14 would set collision for tiles 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14.The `collides` parameter controls if collision will be enabled (true) or disabled (false).

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: The first index of the tile to be set for collision.

parameters.name: stop
parameters.description: The last index of the tile to be set for collision.

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true it will enable collision. If false it will clear collision.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

parameters.name: recalculate
parameters.description: Recalculates the tile faces after the update.

functions.name: setCollisionByExclusion
functions.description: Sets collision on all tiles in the given layer, except for the IDs of those in the given array.The `collides` parameter controls if collision will be enabled (true) or disabled (false).

parameters.name: indexes
parameters.description: An array of the tile IDs to not be counted for collision.

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true it will enable collision. If false it will clear collision.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

parameters.name: recalculate
parameters.description: Recalculates the tile faces after the update.

functions.name: setCollisionByIndex
functions.description: Sets collision values on a tile in the set.You shouldn't usually call this method directly, instead use setCollision, setCollisionBetween or setCollisionByExclusion.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the tile on the layer.

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true it will enable collision on the tile. If false it will clear collision values from the tile.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

parameters.name: recalculate
parameters.description: Recalculates the tile faces after the update.

functions.name: getLayer
functions.description: Gets the TilemapLayer index as used in the setCollision calls.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to this.currentLayer.

returns.description: The TilemapLayer index.

functions.name: setPreventRecalculate
functions.description: Turn off/on the recalculation of faces for tile or collision updates. `setPreventRecalculate(true)` puts recalculation on hold while `setPreventRecalculate(false)` recalculates all the changed layers.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: If true it will put the recalculation on hold.

functions.description: Internal function.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The index of the TilemapLayer to operate on.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The local layer index to get the tile from. Can be determined by Tilemap.getLayer().

parameters.name: x

parameters.name: y

parameters.description: The local layer index to get the tile from. Can be determined by Tilemap.getLayer().

parameters.description: The x coordinate to get the tile from. In tiles, not pixels.

parameters.name: y

functions.name: hasTile
functions.description: Checks if there is a tile at the given location.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position to check if a tile exists at (given in tile units, not pixels)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position to check if a tile exists at (given in tile units, not pixels)

functions.name: removeTile

parameters.name: y

parameters.name: layer
