functions.name: putTile
functions.description: Puts a tile of the given index value at the coordinate specified.If you pass `null` as the tile it will pass your call over to Tilemap.removeTile instead.

parameters.name: tile

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position to insert the tile (given in pixels)

parameters.description: Y position to insert the tile (given in pixels)

parameters.name: tileWidth

parameters.name: tileHeight

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to modify.

returns.description: The Tile object that was created or added to this map.

functions.name: searchTileIndex
functions.description: Searches the entire map layer for the first tile matching the given index, then returns that Phaser.Tile object.If no match is found it returns null.The search starts from the top-left tile and continues horizontally until it hits the end of the row, then it drops down to the next column.If the reverse boolean is true, it scans starting from the bottom-right corner traveling up to the top-left.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The tile index value to search for.

parameters.name: skip
parameters.description: The number of times to skip a matching tile before returning.

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: If true it will scan the layer in reverse, starting at the bottom-right. Otherwise it scans from the top-left.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to get the tile from.

returns.description: The first (or n skipped) tile with the matching index.

functions.name: getTile
functions.description: Gets a tile from the Tilemap Layer. The coordinates are given in tile values.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position to get the tile from (given in tile units, not pixels)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position to get the tile from (given in tile units, not pixels)

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to get the tile from.

parameters.name: nonNull
parameters.description: If true getTile won't return null for empty tiles, but a Tile object with an index of -1.

returns.description: The tile at the given coordinates or null if no tile was found or the coordinates were invalid.

functions.name: getTileWorldXY
functions.description: Gets a tile from the Tilemap layer. The coordinates are given in pixel values.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position to get the tile from (given in pixels)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position to get the tile from (given in pixels)

parameters.name: tileWidth

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The height of the tiles. If not given the map default is used.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to get the tile from.

parameters.name: nonNull
parameters.description: If true getTile won't return null for empty tiles, but a Tile object with an index of -1.

classes.name: Phaser.TilemapLayer
classes.description: A TilemapLayer is a Phaser.Image/Sprite that renders a specific TileLayer of a Tilemap.Since a TilemapLayer is a Sprite it can be moved around the display, added to other groups or display objects, etc.By default TilemapLayers have fixedToCamera set to `true`. Changing this will break Camera follow and scrolling behavior.

constructor.name: TilemapLayer
constructor.description: A TilemapLayer is a Phaser.Image/Sprite that renders a specific TileLayer of a Tilemap.Since a TilemapLayer is a Sprite it can be moved around the display, added to other groups or display objects, etc.By default TilemapLayers have fixedToCamera set to `true`. Changing this will break Camera follow and scrolling behavior.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: Game reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: tilemap
parameters.description: The tilemap to which this layer belongs.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the TileLayer to render within the Tilemap.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: Width of the renderable area of the layer (in pixels).

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: Height of the renderable area of the layer (in pixels).

functions.name: ensureSharedCopyCanvas
functions.description: Create if needed (and return) a shared copy canvas that is shared across all TilemapLayers.Code that uses the canvas is responsible to ensure the dimensions and save/restore state as appropriate.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Automatically called by World.preUpdate.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Automatically called by World.postUpdate. Handles cache updates.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this TilemapLayer.

functions.name: resize
functions.description: Resizes the internal canvas and texture frame used by this TilemapLayer.This is an expensive call, so don't bind it to a window resize event! But instead call it at carefullyselected times.Be aware that no validation of the new sizes takes place and the current map scroll coordinates are notmodified either. You will have to handle both of these things from your game code if required.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The new width of the TilemapLayer

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The new height of the TilemapLayer

functions.name: resizeWorld
functions.description: Sets the world size to match the size of this layer.

functions.name: _fixX
functions.description: Take an x coordinate that doesn't account for scrollFactorX and 'fix' it into a scrolled local space.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: x coordinate in camera space

returns.description: x coordinate in scrollFactor-adjusted dimensions

functions.name: _unfixX
functions.description: Take an x coordinate that _does_ account for scrollFactorX and 'unfix' it back to camera space.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: x coordinate in scrollFactor-adjusted dimensions

returns.description: x coordinate in camera space

functions.name: _fixY
functions.description: Take a y coordinate that doesn't account for scrollFactorY and 'fix' it into a scrolled local space.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: y coordinate in camera space

returns.description: y coordinate in scrollFactor-adjusted dimensions

functions.name: _unfixY
functions.description: Take a y coordinate that _does_ account for scrollFactorY and 'unfix' it back to camera space.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: y coordinate in scrollFactor-adjusted dimensions

returns.description: y coordinate in camera space

functions.name: getTileX
functions.description: Convert a pixel value to a tile coordinate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the point in target tile (in pixels).

returns.description: The X map location of the tile.

functions.name: getTileY
functions.description: Convert a pixel value to a tile coordinate.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the point in target tile (in pixels).

returns.description: The Y map location of the tile.

functions.name: getTileXY
functions.description: Convert a pixel coordinate to a tile coordinate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the point in target tile (in pixels).

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the point in target tile (in pixels).

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The Point/object to update.

returns.description: A Point/object with its `x` and `y` properties set.

functions.name: getRayCastTiles
functions.description: Gets all tiles that intersect with the given line.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line used to determine which tiles to return.

parameters.name: stepRate
parameters.description: How many steps through the ray will we check? Defaults to `rayStepRate`.

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true, _only_ return tiles that collide on one or more faces.

parameters.name: interestingFace
parameters.description: If true, _only_ return tiles that have interesting faces.

returns.description: An array of Phaser.Tiles.

functions.name: getTiles
functions.description: Get all tiles that exist within the given area, defined by the top-left corner, width and height. Values given are in pixels, not tiles.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the top left corner (in pixels).

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the top left corner (in pixels).

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: Width of the area to get (in pixels).

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: Height of the area to get (in pixels).

parameters.name: collides
parameters.description: If true, _only_ return tiles that collide on one or more faces.

parameters.name: interestingFace
parameters.description: If true, _only_ return tiles that have interesting faces.

returns.description: An array of Tiles.

functions.name: resolveTileset
functions.description: Returns the appropriate tileset for the index, updating the internal cache as required.This should only be called if `tilesets[index]` evaluates to undefined.

parameters.name: Tile
parameters.description: index

returns.description: Returns the associated tileset or null if there is no such mapping.

functions.name: resetTilesetCache
functions.description: The TilemapLayer caches tileset look-ups.Call this method of clear the cache if tilesets have been added or updated after the layer has been rendered.

functions.name: setScale
functions.description: This method will set the scale of the tilemap as well as update the underlying block data of this layer

parameters.name: xScale
parameters.description: The scale factor along the X-plane

parameters.name: yScale
parameters.description: The scale factor along the Y-plane

functions.name: shiftCanvas
functions.description: Shifts the contents of the canvas - does extra math so that different browsers agree on the result.The specified (x/y) will be shifted to (0,0) after the copy and the newly exposed canvas area will need to be filled in.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context to shift

functions.name: renderRegion
functions.description: Render tiles in the given area given by the virtual tile coordinates biased by the given scroll factor.This will constrain the tile coordinates based on wrapping but not physical coordinates.

parameters.name: scrollX
parameters.description: Render x offset/scroll.

parameters.name: scrollY
parameters.description: Render y offset/scroll.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: Leftmost column to render.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: Topmost row to render.

parameters.name: right
parameters.description: Rightmost column to render.

parameters.name: bottom
parameters.description: Bottommost row to render.

functions.name: renderDeltaScroll
functions.description: Shifts the canvas and render damaged edge tiles.

functions.name: renderFull
functions.description: Clear and render the entire canvas.

functions.name: render
functions.description: Renders the tiles to the layer canvas and pushes to the display.

functions.name: renderDebug
functions.description: Renders a debug overlay on-top of the canvas. Called automatically by render when `debug` is true.See `debugSettings` for assorted configuration options.

functions.name: setTexture
functions.description:
Sets the texture of the sprite. Be warned that this doesn't remove or destroy the previous
texture this Sprite was using.

parameters.name: texture
parameters.description: The PIXI texture that is displayed by the sprite

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: Call Texture.destroy on the current texture before replacing it with the new one?

functions.name: onTextureUpdate
functions.description: When the texture is updated, this event will fire to update the scale and frame

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the bounds of the Sprite as a rectangle. The bounds calculation takes the worldTransform into account.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: the transformation matrix of the sprite

returns.description: the framing rectangle

functions.name: _renderWebGL
functions.description: Renders the object using the WebGL renderer

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: - Optional matrix. If provided the Display Object will be rendered using this matrix, otherwise it will use its worldTransform.

functions.name: _renderCanvas
functions.description: Renders the object using the Canvas renderer

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: - Optional matrix. If provided the Display Object will be rendered using this matrix, otherwise it will use its worldTransform.

functions.name: addChild
functions.description: Adds a child to the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to add to the container

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: addChildAt
functions.description: Adds a child to the container at a specified index. If the index is out of bounds an error will be thrown

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to add

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to place the child in

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: swapChildren
functions.description: Swaps the position of 2 Display Objects within this container.

functions.name: getChildIndex
functions.description: Returns the index position of a child DisplayObject instance

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject instance to identify

returns.description: The index position of the child display object to identify

functions.name: setChildIndex
functions.description: Changes the position of an existing child in the display object container

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child DisplayObject instance for which you want to change the index number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The resulting index number for the child display object

functions.name: getChildAt
functions.description: Returns the child at the specified index

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child at the given index, if any.

functions.name: removeChild
functions.description: Removes a child from the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to remove

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildAt
functions.description: Removes a child from the specified index position.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildren
functions.description: Removes all children from this container that are within the begin and end indexes.

parameters.name: beginIndex
parameters.description: The beginning position. Default value is 0.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The ending position. Default value is size of the container.

functions.name: getLocalBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: setStageReference
functions.description: Sets the containers Stage reference. This is the Stage that this object, and all of its children, is connected to.

parameters.name: stage
parameters.description: the stage that the container will have as its current stage reference

functions.name: removeStageReference
functions.description: Removes the current stage reference from the container and all of its children.

functions.name: generateTexture
functions.description:
Useful function that returns a texture of the displayObject object that can then be used to create sprites
This can be quite useful if your displayObject is static / complicated and needs to be reused multiple times.

parameters.name: resolution
parameters.description: The resolution of the texture being generated

parameters.name: scaleMode
parameters.description: See {{#crossLink "PIXI/scaleModes:property"}}PIXI.scaleModes{{/crossLink}} for possible values

parameters.name: renderer
parameters.description: The renderer used to generate the texture.

returns.description: a texture of the graphics object

functions.name: updateCache
functions.description: Generates and updates the cached sprite for this object.

functions.name: toGlobal
functions.description: Calculates the global position of the display object

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The world origin to calculate from

returns.description: A point object representing the position of this object

functions.name: toLocal
functions.description: Calculates the local position of the display object relative to another point

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The world origin to calculate from

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to calculate the global position from

returns.description: A point object representing the position of this object

functions.name: _renderCachedSprite
functions.description: Internal method.

parameters.name: renderSession
parameters.description: The render session

functions.name: _generateCachedSprite
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: _destroyCachedSprite
functions.description: Destroys the cached sprite.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Override this method in your own custom objects to handle any update requirements.It is called immediately after `preUpdate` and before `postUpdate`.Remember if this Game Object has any children you should call update on those too.

functions.name: play
functions.description: Plays an Animation.The animation should have previously been created via `animations.add`.If the animation is already playing calling this again won't do anything.If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself or via `AnimationManager.stop`.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump". Must have been previously created via 'AnimationManager.add'.

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.description: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.description: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.description: A reference to playing Animation.

functions.name: bringToTop
functions.description: Brings this Game Object to the top of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render over the top of any old child in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will bring it to the top of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: sendToBack
functions.description: Sends this Game Object to the bottom of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render below all other children in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will send it to the bottom of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: Moves this Game Object up one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the top of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object up within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: Moves this Game Object down one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the bottom of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object down within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: crop
functions.description: Crop allows you to crop the texture being used to display this Game Object.Setting a crop rectangle modifies the core texture frame. The Game Object width and height properties will be adjusted accordingly.Cropping takes place from the top-left and can be modified in real-time either by providing an updated rectangle object to this method,or by modifying `cropRect` property directly and then calling `updateCrop`.The rectangle object given to this method can be either a `Phaser.Rectangle` or any other object so long as it has public `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `right` and `bottom` properties.A reference to the rectangle is stored in `cropRect` unless the `copy` parameter is `true`, in which case the values are duplicated to a local object.

parameters.name: rect
parameters.description: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.description: If false `cropRect` will be stored as a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Phaser Rectangle object stored in cropRect.

functions.name: updateCrop
functions.description: If you have set a crop rectangle on this Game Object via `crop` and since modified the `cropRect` property,or the rectangle it references, then you need to update the crop frame by calling this method.

functions.name: revive
functions.description: Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: kill
functions.description: Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool, it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: loadTexture
functions.description: Changes the base texture the Game Object is using. The old texture is removed and the new one is referenced or fetched from the Cache.If your Game Object is using a frame from a texture atlas and you just wish to change to another frame, then see the `frame` or `frameName` properties instead.You should only use `loadTexture` if you want to replace the base texture entirely.Calling this method causes a WebGL texture update, so use sparingly or in low-intensity portions of your game, or if you know the new texture is already on the GPU.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

parameters.name: stopAnimation
parameters.description: If an animation is already playing on this Sprite you can choose to stop it or let it carry on playing.

functions.name: setFrame
functions.description: Sets the texture frame the Game Object uses for rendering.This is primarily an internal method used by `loadTexture`, but is exposed for the use of plugins and custom classes.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The Frame to be used by the texture.

functions.name: resizeFrame
functions.description: Resizes the Frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.You shouldn't normally need to ever call this, but in the case of special texture types such as Video or BitmapDatait can be useful to adjust the dimensions directly in this way.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent texture object that caused the resize, i.e. a Phaser.Video object.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The new width of the texture.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The new height of the texture.

functions.name: resetFrame
functions.description: Resets the texture frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.

functions.name: overlap
functions.description: Checks to see if the bounds of this Game Object overlaps with the bounds of the given Display Object, which can be a Sprite, Image, TileSprite or anything that extends those such as Button or provides a `getBounds` method and result.This check ignores the `hitArea` property if set and runs a `getBounds` comparison on both objects to determine the result.Therefore it's relatively expensive to use in large quantities, i.e. with lots of Sprites at a high frequency.It should be fine for low-volume testing where physics isn't required.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to check against.

returns.description: True if the bounds of this Game Object intersects at any point with the bounds of the given display object.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: checkTransform
functions.description: Adjust scaling limits, if set, to this Game Object.

parameters.name: wt
parameters.description: The updated worldTransform matrix.

functions.name: setScaleMinMax
functions.description: Sets the scaleMin and scaleMax values. These values are used to limit how far this Game Object will scale based on its parent.For example if this Game Object has a `minScale` value of 1 and its parent has a `scale` value of 0.5, the 0.5 will be ignored and the scale value of 1 will be used, as the parents scale is lower than the minimum scale this Game Object should adhere to.By setting these values you can carefully control how Game Objects deal with responsive scaling.If only one parameter is given then that value will be used for both scaleMin and scaleMax:`setScaleMinMax(1)` = scaleMin.x, scaleMin.y, scaleMax.x and scaleMax.y all = 1If only two parameters are given the first is set as scaleMin.x and y and the second as scaleMax.x and y:`setScaleMinMax(0.5, 2)` = scaleMin.x and y = 0.5 and scaleMax.x and y = 2If you wish to set `scaleMin` with different values for x and y then either modify Game Object.scaleMin directly, or pass `null` for the `maxX` and `maxY` parameters.Call `setScaleMinMax(null)` to clear all previously set values.

parameters.name: minX
parameters.description: The minimum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: minY
parameters.description: The minimum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: maxX
parameters.description: The maximum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

parameters.name: maxY
parameters.description: The maximum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

members.name: map
members.description: The Tilemap to which this layer is bound.

members.name: index
members.description: The index of this layer within the Tilemap.

members.name: layer
members.description: The layer object within the Tilemap that this layer represents.

members.name: canvas
members.description: The canvas to which this TilemapLayer draws.

members.name: context
members.description: The 2d context of the canvas.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: renderSettings
members.description: Settings that control standard (non-diagnostic) rendering.

members.name: debug
members.description: Enable an additional "debug rendering" pass to display collision information.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if the core game loop and physics update this game object or not.

members.name: debugSettings
members.description: Settings used for debugging and diagnostics.

members.name: scrollFactorX
members.description: Speed at which this layer scrolls horizontally, relative to the camera (e.g. scrollFactorX of 0.5 scrolls half as quickly as the 'normal' camera-locked layers do).

members.name: scrollFactorY
members.description: Speed at which this layer scrolls vertically, relative to the camera (e.g. scrollFactorY of 0.5 scrolls half as quickly as the 'normal' camera-locked layers do)

members.name: dirty
members.description: If true tiles will be force rendered, even if such is not believed to be required.

members.name: rayStepRate
members.description: When ray-casting against tiles this is the number of steps it will jump. For larger tile sizes you can increase this to improve performance.

members.name: _wrap
members.description: Flag controlling if the layer tiles wrap at the edges.

members.name: _mc
members.description: Local map data and calculation cache.

members.name: _scrollX
members.description: The current canvas left after scroll is applied.

members.name: _scrollY
members.description: The current canvas top after scroll is applied.

members.name: _results
members.description: Used for caching the tiles / array of tiles.

members.name: sharedCopyCanvas
members.description: The shared double-copy canvas, created as needed.

members.name: anchor
members.description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

members.name: texture
members.description: The texture that the sprite is using

members.name: _width
members.description: The width of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: _height
members.description: The height of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: tint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: cachedTint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: tintedTexture
members.description: A canvas that contains the tinted version of the Sprite (in Canvas mode, WebGL doesn't populate this)

members.name: blendMode
members.description:
The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

Warning: You cannot have a blend mode and a filter active on the same Sprite. Doing so will render the sprite invisible.

members.name: shader
members.description: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: position
members.description: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: scale
members.description: The scale factor of the object.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

members.name: pivot
members.description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

members.name: rotation
members.description: The rotation of the object in radians.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The opacity of the object.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility of the object.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description: Can this object be rendered

members.name: parent
members.description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

members.name: stage
members.description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

members.name: worldTransform
members.description: [read-only] Current transform of the object based on world (parent) factors

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

members.name: _sr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: _cr
members.description: cached sin rotation and cos rotation

members.name: filterArea
members.description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

members.name: _bounds
members.description: The original, cached bounds of the object

members.name: _currentBounds
members.description: The most up-to-date bounds of the object

members.name: _mask
members.description: The original, cached mask of the object

members.name: _cacheAsBitmap
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: _cacheIsDirty
members.description: Cached internal flag.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.
In PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.
To remove a mask, set this property to null.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for the displayObject.
IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the Canvas renderer.

To remove filters simply set this property to 'null'.

You cannot have a filter and a multiply blend mode active at the same time. Setting a filter will reset
this objects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.
This basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.
To remove simply set this property to 'null'

members.name: x
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: y
members.description: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A user defined name given to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, it is meant as a game level property.

members.name: components
members.description: The components this Game Object has installed.

members.name: z
members.description: The z depth of this Game Object within its parent Group.No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.This value is adjusted automatically whenever the Group hierarchy changes.

members.name: events
members.description: All Phaser Game Objects have an Events class which contains all of the events that are dispatched when certain things happen to thisGame Object, or any of its components.

members.name: animations
members.description: If the Game Object is enabled for animation (such as a Phaser.Sprite) this is a reference to its AnimationManager instance.Through it you can create, play, pause and stop animations.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the image or texture used by this Game Object during rendering.If it is a string it's the string used to retrieve the texture from the Phaser Image Cache.It can also be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.If a Game Object is created without a key it is automatically assigned the key `__default` which is a 32x32 transparent PNG stored within the Cache.If a Game Object is given a key which doesn't exist in the Image Cache it is re-assigned the key `__missing` which is a 32x32 PNG of a green box with a line through it.

members.name: world
members.description: The world coordinates of this Game Object in pixels.Depending on where in the display list this Game Object is placed this value can differ from `position`, which contains the x/y coordinates relative to the Game Objects parent.

members.name: previousPosition
members.description: The position the Game Object was located in the previous frame.

members.name: previousRotation
members.description: The rotation the Game Object was in set to in the previous frame. Value is in radians.

members.name: renderOrderID
members.description: The render order ID is used internally by the renderer and Input Manager and should not be modified.This property is mostly used internally by the renderers, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: fresh
members.description: A Game Object is considered `fresh` if it has just been created or reset and is yet to receive a renderer transform update.This property is mostly used internally by the physics systems, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Game Object is that is pendingDestroy is flagged to have its destroy method called on the next logic update.You can set it directly to allow you to flag an object to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy an object from within one of its own callbacks such as with Buttons or other Input events.

members.name: _exists
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle property is the rotation of the Game Object in *degrees* from its original orientation.Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees you can use the property `rotation` instead. Working in radians is slightly faster as it doesn't have to perform any calculations.

members.name: autoCull
members.description: A Game Object with `autoCull` set to true will check its bounds against the World Camera every frame.If it is not intersecting the Camera bounds at any point then it has its `renderable` property set to `false`.This keeps the Game Object alive and still processing updates, but forces it to skip the render step entirely.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: inCamera
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds intersect with the Game Camera bounds.Returns `true` if they do, otherwise `false` if fully outside of the Cameras bounds.

members.name: offsetX
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its x coordinate.This is the same as `width * anchor.x`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.x is not equal to zero.

members.name: offsetY
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its y coordinate.This is the same as `height * anchor.y`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.y is not equal to zero.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x - offsetX`.

members.name: right
members.description: The right coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x + width - offsetX`.

members.name: top
members.description: The y coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `y - offsetY`.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and height properties.This is the same as `y + height - offsetY`.

members.name: cropRect
members.description: The Rectangle used to crop the texture this Game Object uses.Set this property via `crop`. If you modify this property directly you must call `updateCrop` in order to have the change take effect.

members.name: _crop
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: deltaX
members.description: Returns the delta x value. The difference between world.x now and in the previous frame.The value will be positive if the Game Object has moved to the right or negative if to the left.

members.name: deltaY
members.description: Returns the delta y value. The difference between world.y now and in the previous frame.The value will be positive if the Game Object has moved down or negative if up.

members.name: deltaZ
members.description: Returns the delta z value. The difference between rotation now and in the previous frame. The delta value.

members.name: destroyPhase
members.description: As a Game Object runs through its destroy method this flag is set to true, and can be checked in any sub-systems or plugins it is being destroyed from.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Game Object that is "fixed" to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera during rendering.The values are adjusted at the rendering stage, overriding the Game Objects actual world position.The end result is that the Game Object will appear to be 'fixed' to the camera, regardless of where in the game worldthe camera is viewing. This is useful if for example this Game Object is a UI item that you wish to be visible at all times regardless where in the world the camera is.The offsets are stored in the `cameraOffset` property.Note that the `cameraOffset` values are in addition to any parent of this Game Object on the display list.Be careful not to set `fixedToCamera` on Game Objects which are in Groups that already have `fixedToCamera` enabled on them.

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: The x/y coordinate offset applied to the top-left of the camera that this Game Object will be drawn at if `fixedToCamera` is true.The values are relative to the top-left of the camera view and in addition to any parent of the Game Object on the display list.

members.name: health
members.description: The Game Objects health value. This is a handy property for setting and manipulating health on a Game Object.It can be used in combination with the `damage` method or modified directly.

members.name: maxHealth
members.description: The Game Objects maximum health value. This works in combination with the `heal` method to ensurethe health value never exceeds the maximum.

members.name: damage
members.description: Damages the Game Object. This removes the given amount of health from the `health` property.If health is taken below or is equal to zero then the `kill` method is called.

members.name: heal
members.description: Heal the Game Object. This adds the given amount of health to the `health` property.

members.name: input
members.description: The Input Handler for this Game Object.By default it is disabled. If you wish this Game Object to process input events you should enable it with: `inputEnabled = true`.After you have done this, this property will be a reference to the Phaser InputHandler.

members.name: inputEnabled
members.description: By default a Game Object won't process any input events. By setting `inputEnabled` to true a Phaser.InputHandler is createdfor this Game Object and it will then start to process click / touch events and more.You can then access the Input Handler via `this.input`.Note that Input related events are dispatched from `this.events`, i.e.: `events.onInputDown`.If you set this property to false it will stop the Input Handler from processing any more input events.

members.name: checkWorldBounds
members.description: If this is set to `true` the Game Object checks if it is within the World bounds each frame. When it is no longer intersecting the world bounds it dispatches the `onOutOfBounds` event.If it was *previously* out of bounds but is now intersecting the world bounds again it dispatches the `onEnterBounds` event.It also optionally kills the Game Object if `outOfBoundsKill` is `true`.When `checkWorldBounds` is enabled it forces the Game Object to calculate its full bounds every frame.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: outOfBoundsKill
members.description: If this and the `checkWorldBounds` property are both set to `true` then the `kill` method is called as soon as `inWorld` returns false.

members.name: _outOfBoundsFired
members.description: Internal state var.

members.name: inWorld
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds are within, or intersect at any point with the Game World bounds.

members.name: alive
members.description: A useful flag to control if the Game Object is alive or dead.This is set automatically by the Health components `damage` method should the object run out of health.Or you can toggle it via your game code.This property is mostly just provided to be used by your game - it doesn't effect rendering or logic updates.However you can use `Group.getFirstAlive` in conjunction with this property for fast object pooling and recycling.

members.name: lifespan
members.description: The lifespan allows you to give a Game Object a lifespan in milliseconds.Once the Game Object is 'born' you can set this to a positive value.It is automatically decremented by the millisecond equivalent of `game.time.physicsElapsed` each frame.When it reaches zero it will call the `kill` method.Very handy for particles, bullets, collectibles, or any other short-lived entity.

members.name: customRender
members.description: Does this texture require a custom render call? (as set by BitmapData, Video, etc)

members.name: _frame
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: frame
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame index of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frame` to the index of the new frame in the sprite sheet you wish this Game Object to use,for example: `player.frame = 4`.If the frame index given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture.If you are using a texture atlas then you should use the `frameName` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: frameName
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame name of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frameName` to the name of the new frame in the texture atlas you wish this Game Object to use, for example: `player.frameName = "idle"`.If the frame name given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture and throw a console warning.If you are using a sprite sheet then you should use the `frame` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: body
members.description: `body` is the Game Objects physics body. Once a Game Object is enabled for physics you access all associated properties and methods via it.By default Game Objects won't add themselves to any physics system and their `body` property will be `null`.To enable this Game Object for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(object, system)` where `object` is this objectand `system` is the Physics system you are using. If none is given it defaults to `Phaser.Physics.Arcade`.You can alternatively call `game.physics.arcade.enable(object)`, or add this Game Object to a physics enabled Group.Important: Enabling a Game Object for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set its `anchor` property to 0.5, so the physics body is centered on the Game Object.If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

members.name: scaleMin
members.description: The minimum scale this Game Object will scale down to.It allows you to prevent a parent from scaling this Game Object lower than the given value.Set it to `null` to remove the limit.

members.name: scaleMax
members.description: The maximum scale this Game Object will scale up to. It allows you to prevent a parent from scaling this Game Object higher than the given value.Set it to `null` to remove the limit.

members.name: smoothed
members.description: Enable or disable texture smoothing for this Game Object.It only takes effect if the Game Object is using an image based texture.Smoothing is enabled by default.

classes.name: Phaser.TilemapParser
classes.description: Phaser.TilemapParser parses data objects from Phaser.Loader that need more preparation before they can be inserted into a Tilemap.

constructor.name: TilemapParser

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the tilemap in the Cache.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The pixel width of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The pixel height of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.

returns.description: The parsed map object.

functions.name: parseCSV
functions.description: Parses a CSV file into valid map data.

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: The CSV file data.

parameters.name: tileWidth
parameters.description: The pixel width of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

parameters.name: tileHeight
parameters.description: The pixel height of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.

returns.description: Generated map data.

functions.name: getEmptyData
functions.description: Returns an empty map data object.

returns.description: Generated map data.

functions.name: parseJSON
functions.description: Parses a Tiled JSON file into valid map data.

parameters.name: json
parameters.description: The JSON map data.

returns.description: Generated and parsed map data.

members.name: INSERT_NULL
members.description: When scanning the Tiled map data the TilemapParser can either insert a null value (true) or a Phaser.Tile instance with an index of -1 (false, the default). Depending on your game typedepends how this should be configured. If you've a large sparsely populated map and the tiledata doesn't need to change then setting this value to `true` will help with memory consumption.However if your map is small, or you need to update the tiles (perhaps the map dynamically changesduring the game) then leave the default value set.

classes.name: Phaser.Tileset
classes.description: A Tile set is a combination of an image containing the tiles and collision data per tile.Tilesets are normally created automatically when Tiled data is loaded.

members.name: columns

members.name: total

classes.name: Phaser.Time
classes.description: This is the core internal game clock.It manages the elapsed time and calculation of elapsed values, used for game object motion and tweens,and also handles the standard Timer pool.To create a general timed event, use the master {@link Phaser.Timer} accessible through {@link Phaser.Time.events events}.

constructor.name: Time
constructor.description: This is the core internal game clock.It manages the elapsed time and calculation of elapsed values, used for game object motion and tweens,and also handles the standard Timer pool.To create a general timed event, use the master {@link Phaser.Timer} accessible through {@link Phaser.Time.events events}.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

functions.name: boot
functions.description: Called automatically by Phaser.Game after boot. Should not be called directly.

functions.name: add
functions.description: Adds an existing Phaser.Timer object to the Timer pool.

parameters.name: timer
parameters.description: An existing Phaser.Timer object.

returns.description: The given Phaser.Timer object.

functions.name: create
functions.description: Creates a new stand-alone Phaser.Timer object.

parameters.name: autoDestroy
parameters.description: A Timer that is set to automatically destroy itself will do so after all of its events have been dispatched (assuming no looping events).

returns.description: The Timer object that was created.

functions.name: removeAll
functions.description: Remove all Timer objects, regardless of their state and clears all Timers from the {@link Phaser.Time#events events} timer.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Updates the game clock and if enabled the advanced timing data. This is called automatically by Phaser.Game.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The current relative timestamp; see {@link Phaser.Time#now now}.

functions.name: updateSetTimeout
functions.description: setTimeOut specific time update handler.Called automatically by Time.update.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The current relative timestamp; see {@link Phaser.Time#now now}.

functions.name: updateRAF
functions.description: raf specific time update handler.Called automatically by Time.update.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The current relative timestamp; see {@link Phaser.Time#now now}.

functions.name: updateTimers
functions.description: Handles the updating of the Phaser.Timers (if any)Called automatically by Time.update.

functions.name: updateAdvancedTiming
functions.description: Handles the updating of the advanced timing values (if enabled)Called automatically by Time.update.

functions.name: gamePaused
functions.description: Called when the game enters a paused state.

functions.name: gameResumed
functions.description: Called when the game resumes from a paused state.

functions.name: totalElapsedSeconds
functions.description: The number of seconds that have elapsed since the game was started.

returns.description: The number of seconds that have elapsed since the game was started.

functions.name: elapsedSince
functions.description: How long has passed since the given time.

parameters.name: since
parameters.description: The time you want to measure against.

returns.description: The difference between the given time and now.

functions.name: elapsedSecondsSince
functions.description: How long has passed since the given time (in seconds).

parameters.name: since
parameters.description: The time you want to measure (in seconds).

returns.description: Duration between given time and now (in seconds).

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the private _started value to now and removes all currently running Timers.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: time
members.description: The `Date.now()` value when the time was last updated.

members.name: prevTime
members.description: The `now` when the previous update occurred.

members.name: now
members.description: An increasing value representing cumulative milliseconds since an undisclosed epoch.While this value is in milliseconds and can be used to compute time deltas,it must must _not_ be used with `Date.now()` as it may not use the same epoch / starting reference.The source may either be from a high-res source (eg. if RAF is available) or the standard Date.now;the value can only be relied upon within a particular game instance.

members.name: elapsed
members.description: Elapsed time since the last time update, in milliseconds, based on `now`.This value _may_ include time that the game is paused/inactive._Note:_ This is updated only once per game loop - even if multiple logic update steps are done.Use {@link Phaser.Timer#physicsTime physicsTime} as a basis of game/logic calculations instead.

members.name: elapsedMS
members.description: The time in ms since the last time update, in milliseconds, based on `time`.This value is corrected for game pauses and will be "about zero" after a game is resumed._Note:_ This is updated once per game loop - even if multiple logic update steps are done.Use {@link Phaser.Timer#physicsTime physicsTime} as a basis of game/logic calculations instead.

members.name: physicsElapsed
members.description: The physics update delta, in fractional seconds.This should be used as an applicable multiplier by all logic update steps (eg. `preUpdate/postUpdate/update`)to ensure consistent game timing. Game/logic timing can drift from real-world time if the systemis unable to consistently maintain the desired FPS.With fixed-step updates this is normally equivalent to `1.0 / desiredFps`.

members.name: physicsElapsedMS
members.description: The physics update delta, in milliseconds - equivalent to `physicsElapsed * 1000`.

members.name: desiredFps
members.description: The desired frame rate of the game.This is used is used to calculate the physic/logic multiplier and how to apply catch-up logic updates.

members.name: suggestedFps
members.description: The suggested frame rate for your game, based on an averaged real frame rate.This value is only populated if `Time.advancedTiming` is enabled._Note:_ This is not available until after a few frames have passed; use it after a few seconds (eg. after the menus)

members.name: slowMotion
members.description: Scaling factor to make the game move smoothly in slow motion- 1.0 = normal speed- 2.0 = half speed

members.name: advancedTiming
members.description: If true then advanced profiling, including the fps rate, fps min/max, suggestedFps and msMin/msMax are updated.

members.name: frames
members.description: Advanced timing result: The number of render frames record in the last second.Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.

members.name: fps
members.description: Advanced timing result: Frames per second.Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.

members.name: fpsMin
members.description: Advanced timing result: The lowest rate the fps has dropped to.Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.This value can be manually reset.

members.name: fpsMax
members.description: Advanced timing result: The highest rate the fps has reached (usually no higher than 60fps).Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.This value can be manually reset.

members.name: msMin
members.description: Advanced timing result: The minimum amount of time the game has taken between consecutive frames.Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.This value can be manually reset.

members.name: msMax
members.description: Advanced timing result: The maximum amount of time the game has taken between consecutive frames.Only calculated if {@link Phaser.Time#advancedTiming advancedTiming} is enabled.This value can be manually reset.

members.name: pauseDuration
members.description: Records how long the game was last paused, in milliseconds.(This is not updated until the game is resumed.)

members.name: timeToCall
members.description: The value that setTimeout needs to work out when to next update

members.name: timeExpected
members.description: The time when the next call is expected when using setTimer to control the update loop

members.name: events
members.description: A {@link Phaser.Timer} object bound to the master clock (this Time object) which events can be added to.

members.name: _frameCount
members.description: count the number of calls to time.update since the last suggestedFps was calculated

members.name: _elapsedAccumulator
members.description: sum of the elapsed time since the last suggestedFps was calculated

members.name: _started
members.description: The time at which the Game instance started.

members.name: _timeLastSecond
members.description: The time (in ms) that the last second counter ticked over.

members.name: _pauseStarted
members.description: The time the game started being paused.

members.name: _justResumed
members.description: Internal value used to recover from the game pause state.

members.name: _timers
members.description: Internal store of Phaser.Timer objects.

classes.name: Phaser.Timer
classes.description: A Timer is a way to create small re-usable (or disposable) objects that wait for a specific moment in time,and then run the specified callbacks.You can add many events to a Timer, each with their own delays. A Timer uses milliseconds as its unit of time (there are 1000 ms in 1 second).So a delay to 250 would fire the event every quarter of a second.Timers are based on real-world (not physics) time, adjusted for game pause durations.

constructor.name: Timer
constructor.description: A Timer is a way to create small re-usable (or disposable) objects that wait for a specific moment in time,and then run the specified callbacks.You can add many events to a Timer, each with their own delays. A Timer uses milliseconds as its unit of time (there are 1000 ms in 1 second).So a delay to 250 would fire the event every quarter of a second.Timers are based on real-world (not physics) time, adjusted for game pause durations.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: autoDestroy
parameters.description: If true, the timer will automatically destroy itself after all the events have been dispatched (assuming no looping events).

functions.name: create
functions.description: Creates a new TimerEvent on this Timer.Use {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, or {@link Phaser.Timer#add} methods to create a new event.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds that should elapse before the Timer will call the given callback. This value should be an integer, not a float. Math.round() is applied to it by this method.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the event loop or not?

parameters.name: repeatCount
parameters.description: The number of times the event will repeat.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be called when the Timer event occurs.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: The values to be sent to your callback function when it is called.

returns.description: The Phaser.TimerEvent object that was created.

functions.name: add
functions.description: Adds a new Event to this Timer.The event will fire after the given amount of `delay` in milliseconds has passed, once the Timer has started running.The delay is in relation to when the Timer starts, not the time it was added. If the Timer is already running the delay will be calculated based on the timers current time.Make sure to call {@link Phaser.Timer#start start} after adding all of the Events you require for this Timer.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds that should elapse before the callback is invoked.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be called when the Timer event occurs.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: Additional arguments that will be supplied to the callback.

returns.description: The Phaser.TimerEvent object that was created.

functions.name: repeat
functions.description: Adds a new TimerEvent that will always play through once and then repeat for the given number of iterations.The event will fire after the given amount of `delay` in milliseconds has passed, once the Timer has started running.The delay is in relation to when the Timer starts, not the time it was added. If the Timer is already running the delay will be calculated based on the timers current time.Make sure to call {@link Phaser.Timer#start start} after adding all of the Events you require for this Timer.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds that should elapse before the Timer will call the given callback.

parameters.name: repeatCount
parameters.description: The number of times the event will repeat once is has finished playback. A repeatCount of 1 means it will repeat itself once, playing the event twice in total.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be called when the Timer event occurs.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: Additional arguments that will be supplied to the callback.

returns.description: The Phaser.TimerEvent object that was created.

functions.name: loop
functions.description: Adds a new looped Event to this Timer that will repeat forever or until the Timer is stopped.The event will fire after the given amount of `delay` in milliseconds has passed, once the Timer has started running.The delay is in relation to when the Timer starts, not the time it was added. If the Timer is already running the delay will be calculated based on the timers current time.Make sure to call {@link Phaser.Timer#start start} after adding all of the Events you require for this Timer.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds that should elapse before the Timer will call the given callback.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be called when the Timer event occurs.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: Additional arguments that will be supplied to the callback.

returns.description: The Phaser.TimerEvent object that was created.

functions.name: start
functions.description: Starts this Timer running.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds that should elapse before the Timer will start.

functions.name: stop
functions.description: Stops this Timer from running. Does not cause it to be destroyed if autoDestroy is set to true.

parameters.name: clearEvents
parameters.description: If true all the events in Timer will be cleared, otherwise they will remain.

functions.name: remove
functions.description: Removes a pending TimerEvent from the queue.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The event to remove from the queue.

functions.name: order
functions.description: Orders the events on this Timer so they are in tick order.This is called automatically when new events are created.

functions.name: sortHandler
functions.description: Sort handler used by Phaser.Timer.order.

functions.name: clearPendingEvents
functions.description: Clears any events from the Timer which have pendingDelete set to true and then resets the private _len and _i values.

functions.name: update
functions.description: The main Timer update event, called automatically by Phaser.Time.update.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The time from the core game clock.

returns.description: True if there are still events waiting to be dispatched, otherwise false if this Timer can be destroyed.

functions.name: pause
functions.description: Pauses the Timer and all events in the queue.

functions.name: _pause
functions.description: Internal pause/resume control - user code should use Timer.pause instead.

functions.name: adjustEvents
functions.description: Adjusts the time of all pending events and the nextTick by the given baseTime.

functions.name: resume
functions.description: Resumes the Timer and updates all pending events.

functions.name: _resume
functions.description: Internal pause/resume control - user code should use Timer.resume instead.

functions.name: removeAll
functions.description: Removes all Events from this Timer and all callbacks linked to onComplete, but leaves the Timer running.    The onComplete callbacks won't be called.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this Timer. Any pending Events are not dispatched.The onComplete callbacks won't be called.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: running
members.description: True if the Timer is actively running.Do not modify this boolean - use {@link Phaser.Timer#pause pause} (and {@link Phaser.Timer#resume resume}) to pause the timer.

members.name: autoDestroy
members.description: If true, the timer will automatically destroy itself after all the events have been dispatched (assuming no looping events).

members.name: expired
members.description: An expired Timer is one in which all of its events have been dispatched and none are pending.

members.name: elapsed
members.description: Elapsed time since the last frame (in ms).

members.name: events
members.description: An array holding all of this timers Phaser.TimerEvent objects. Use the methods add, repeat and loop to populate it.

members.name: onComplete
members.description: This signal will be dispatched when this Timer has completed which means that there are no more events in the queue.The signal is supplied with one argument, `timer`, which is this Timer object.

members.name: nextTick
members.description: The time the next tick will occur.

members.name: timeCap
members.description: If the difference in time between two frame updates exceeds this value, the event times are reset to avoid catch-up situations.

members.name: paused
members.description: The paused state of the Timer. You can pause the timer by calling Timer.pause() and Timer.resume() or by the game pausing.

members.name: _codePaused
members.description: Was the Timer paused by code or by Game focus loss?

members.name: _started
members.description: The time at which this Timer instance started running.

members.name: _pauseStarted
members.description: The time the game started being paused.

members.name: _pauseTotal
members.description: Total paused time.

members.name: _now
members.description: The current start-time adjusted time.

members.name: _len
members.description: Temp. array length variable.

members.name: _marked
members.description: Temp. counter variable.

members.name: _i
members.description: Temp. array counter variable.

members.name: _diff
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _newTick
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: MINUTE
members.description: Number of milliseconds in a minute.

members.name: SECOND
members.description: Number of milliseconds in a second.

members.name: HALF
members.description: Number of milliseconds in half a second.

members.name: QUARTER
members.description: Number of milliseconds in a quarter of a second.

members.name: next
members.description: The time at which the next event will occur.

members.name: duration
members.description: The duration in ms remaining until the next event will occur.

members.name: length
members.description: The number of pending events in the queue.

members.name: ms
members.description: The duration in milliseconds that this Timer has been running for.

members.name: seconds
members.description: The duration in seconds that this Timer has been running for.

classes.name: Phaser.TimerEvent
classes.description: A TimerEvent is a single event that is processed by a Phaser.Timer.It consists of a delay, which is a value in milliseconds after which the event will fire.When the event fires it calls a specific callback with the specified arguments.Use {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, or {@link Phaser.Timer#add} methods to create a new event.

constructor.name: TimerEvent
constructor.description: A TimerEvent is a single event that is processed by a Phaser.Timer.It consists of a delay, which is a value in milliseconds after which the event will fire.When the event fires it calls a specific callback with the specified arguments.Use {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, or {@link Phaser.Timer#add} methods to create a new event.

parameters.name: timer
parameters.description: The Timer object that this TimerEvent belongs to.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: The delay in ms at which this TimerEvent fires.

parameters.name: tick
parameters.description: The tick is the next game clock time that this event will fire at.

parameters.name: repeatCount
parameters.description: If this TimerEvent repeats it will do so this many times.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: True if this TimerEvent loops, otherwise false.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback that will be called when the TimerEvent occurs.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: Additional arguments to be passed to the callback.
